books.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 1

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 1:1
verses.text: Refutation of All Heresies Book : The Ophites the Progenitors of Subsequent Heresies.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 1:2
verses.text: Whatever opinions, then, were entertained by those who derived the first principles (of their doctrine) from the serpent, and in process of time deliberately brought forward into public notice their tenets, we have explained in the book preceding this, (and) which is the fifth of the Refutation of Heresies.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 1:3
verses.text: But now also I shall not be silent as regards the opinions of (heresiarchs) who follow these (Ophites in succession); nay, not one (speculation) will I leave unrefuted, if it is possible to remember all (their tenets), and the secret orgies of these (heretics) which one may fairly style orgies,—for they who propagate such audacious opinions are not far distant from the anger (of God),—that I may avail myself of the assistance of etymology.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 2

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 2:1
verses.text: Simon Magus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 2:2
verses.text: It seems, then, expedient likewise to explain now the opinions of Simon, a native of Gitta, a village of Samaria; and we shall also prove that his successors, taking a starting-point from him, have endeavoured (to establish) similar opinions under a change of name.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 2:3
verses.text: This Simon being an adept in sorceries, both making a mockery of many, partly according to the art of Thrasymedes, in the manner in which we have explained above, and partly also by the assistance of demons perpetrating his villany, attempted to deify himself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 2:4
verses.text: (But) the man was a (mere) cheat, and full of folly, and the Apostles reproved him in the Acts.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 2:5
verses.text: With much greater wisdom and moderation than Simon, did Apsethus the Libyan, inflamed with a similar wish, endeavour to have himself considered a god in Libya.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 2:6
verses.text: And inasmuch as his legendary system does not present any wide divergence from the inordinate desire of that silly Simon, it seems expedient to furnish an explanation of it, as one worthy of the attempt made by this man.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 3

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 3:1
verses.text: Story of Apsethus the Libyan.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 3:2
verses.text: Apsethus the Libyan inordinately longed to become a god; but when, after repeated intrigues, he altogether failed to accomplish his desire, he nevertheless wished to appear to have become a god; and he did at all events appear, as time wore on, to have in reality become a god.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 3:3
verses.text: For the foolish Libyans were accustomed to sacrifice unto him as to some divine power, supposing that they were yielding credence to a voice that came down from above, from heaven.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 3:4
verses.text: For, collecting into one and the same cage a great number of birds,—parrots,—he shut them up.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 3:5
verses.text: Now there are very many parrots throughout Libya, and very distinctly these imitate the human voice.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 3:6
verses.text: This man, having for a time nourished the birds, was in the habit of teaching them to say, "Apsethus is a god".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 3:7
verses.text: After, however, the birds had practised this for a long period, and were accustomed to the utterance of that which he thought, when said, would make it supposed that Apsethus was a god, then, opening the habitation (of the birds), he let forth the parrots, each in a different direction.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 3:8
verses.text: While the birds, however, were on the wing, their sound went out into all Libya, and the expressions of these reached as far as the Hellenic country.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 3:9
verses.text: And thus the Libyans, being astonished at the voice of the birds, and not perceiving the knavery perpetrated by Apsethus, held Apsethus to be a god.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 3:10
verses.text: Some one, however, of the Greeks, by accurate examination, perceiving the trick of the supposed god, by means of those same parrots not only refutes, but also utterly destroys, that boastful and tiresome fellow.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 3:11
verses.text: Now the Greek, by confining many of the parrots, taught them anew to say, "Apsethus, having caged us, compelled us to say, Apsethus is a god".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 3:12
verses.text: But having heard of the recantation of the parrots, the Libyans, coming together, all unanimously decided on burning Apsethus.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 4

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 4:1
verses.text: Simon's on drugs; Plagiarizes from Heraclitus and Aristotle; Simon's System of Sensible and Intelligible Existences.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 4:2
verses.text: In this way we must think concerning Simon the magician, so that we may compare him unto the Libyan, far sooner than unto Him who, though made man, was in reality God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 4:3
verses.text: If, however, the assertion of this likeness is in itself accurate, and the sorcerer was the subject of a passion similar to Apsethus, let us endeavour to teach anew the parrots of Simon, that Christ, who stood, stands, and will stand, (that is, was, is, and is to come,) was not Simon.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 4:4
verses.text: But (Jesus) was man, offspring of the seed of a woman, born of blood and the will of the flesh, as also the rest (of humanity).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 4:5
verses.text: And that these things are so, we shall easily prove as the discussion proceeds.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 4:6
verses.text: Now Simon, both foolishly and knavishly paraphrasing the law of Moses, makes his statements (in the manner following): For when Moses asserts that "God is a burning and consuming fire," taking what is said by Moses not in its correct sense, he affirms that fire is the originating principle of the universe.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 4:7
verses.text: (But Simon) does not consider what the statement is which is made, namely, that it is not that God is a fire, but a burning and consuming fire, (thereby) not only putting a violent sense upon the actual law of Moses, but even plagiarizing from Heraclitus the Obscure.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 4:8
verses.text: And Simon denominates the originating principle of the universe an indefinite power, expressing himself thus: "This is the treatise of a revelation of (the) voice and name (recognisable) by means of intellectual apprehension of the Great Indefinite Power.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 4:9
verses.text: Wherefore it will be sealed, (and) kept secret, (and) hid, (and) will repose in the habitation, at the foundation of which lies the root of all things".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 4:10
verses.text: And he asserts that this man who is born of blood is (the aforesaid) habitation, and that in him resides an indefinite power, which he affirms to be the root of the universe.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 4:11
verses.text: Now the indefinite power which is fire, constitutes, according to Simon, not any uncompounded (essence, in conformity with the opinion of those who) assert that the four elements are simple, and who have (therefore) likewise imagined that fire, (which is one of the four,) is simple.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 4:12
verses.text: But (this is far from being the case): for there is, (he maintains,) a certain twofold nature of fire; and of this twofold (nature) he denominates one part a something secret, and another a something manifest, and that the secret are hidden in the manifest portions of the fire, and that the manifest portions of the fire derive their being from its secret (portions).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 4:13
verses.text: This, however, is what Aristotle denominates by (the expressions) "potentiality" and "energy," or (what) Plato (styles) "intelligible" and "sensible".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 4:14
verses.text: And the manifest portion of the fire comprises all things in itself, whatsoever any one might discern, or even whatever objects of the visible creation he may happen to overlook.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 4:15
verses.text: But the entire secret (portion of the fire) which one may discern is cognised by intellect, and evades the power of the senses; or one fails to observe it, from want of a capacity for that particular sort of perception.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 4:16
verses.text: In general, however, inasmuch as all existing things fall under the categories, namely, of what are objects of Sense, and what are objects of Intellect, and as for the denomination of these (Simon) employs the terms secret and manifest; it may, (I say, in general,) be affirmed that the fire, (I mean) the super-celestial (fire), is a treasure, as it were a large tree, just such a one as in a dream was seen by Nabuchodonosor, out of which all flesh is nourished.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 4:17
verses.text: And the manifest portion of the fire he regards as the stem, the branches, the leaves, (and) the external rind which overlaps them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 4:18
verses.text: All these (appendages), he says, of the Great Tree being kindled, are made to disappear by reason of the blaze of the all-devouring fire.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 4:19
verses.text: The fruit, however, of the tree, when it is fully grown, and has received its own form, is deposited in a granary, not (flung) into the fire.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 4:20
verses.text: For, he says, the fruit has been produced for the purpose of being laid in the storehouse, whereas the chaff that it may be delivered over to the fire.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 4:21
verses.text: (Now the chaff) is stem, (and is) generated not for its own sake, but for that of the fruit.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 5

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 5:1
verses.text: Simon Appeals to Scripture in Support of His System.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 5:2
verses.text: And this, he says, is what has been written in Scripture: "For the vineyard of the Lord of Sabaoth is the house of Israel, and the man of Judah is His beloved plant".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 5:3
verses.text: If, however, the man of Judah (is) the beloved plant, it has been proved, he says, that there is not any other tree but that man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 5:4
verses.text: But concerning the secretion and dissolution of this (tree), Scripture, he says, has spoken sufficiently.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 5:5
verses.text: And as regards instruction for those who have been fashioned after the image (of him), that statement is enough which is made (in Scripture), that "all flesh is grass, and all the glory of flesh, as it were, a flower of grass.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 5:6
verses.text: The grass withereth, and its flower falleth; but the word of the Lord abideth for ever".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 5:7
verses.text: The word of the Lord, he says, is that word which is produced in the mouth, and (is) a Logos, but nowhere else exists there a place of generation.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 6

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 6:1
verses.text: Simon's System Expounded in the Work, Great Announcement; Follows Empedocles.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 6:2
verses.text: Now, to express myself briefly, inasmuch as the fire is of this description, according to Simon, and since all things are visible and invisible, (and) in like manner resonant and not resonant, numerable and not subjects of numeration; he denominates in the Great Announcement a perfect intelligible (entity), after such a mode, that each of those things which, existing indefinitely, may be infinitely comprehended, both speaks, and understands, and acts in such a manner as Empedocles speaks of:—  "For earth, indeed, by earth we see, and water by water,  And air divine by air, and fire fierce by fire,  And love by love, and also strife by gloomy strife".

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 7

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 7:1
verses.text: Simon's System of a Threefold Emanation by Pairs.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 7:2
verses.text: For, he says, he is in the habit of considering that all these portions of the fire, both visible and invisible, are possessed of perception and a share of intelligence.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 7:3
verses.text: The world, therefore, that which is generated, was produced from the unbegotten fire.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 7:4
verses.text: It began, however, to exist, he says, according to the following manner.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 7:5
verses.text: He who was begotten from the principle of that fire took six roots, and those primary ones, of the originating principle of generation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 7:6
verses.text: And, he says that the roots were made from the fire in pairs, which roots he terms "Mind" and "Intelligence," "Voice" and "Name," "Ratiocination" and "Reflection".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 7:7
verses.text: And that in these six roots resides simultaneously the entire indefinite power potentially, (however) not actually.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 7:8
verses.text: And this indefinite power, he says, is he who stood, stands, and will stand.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 7:9
verses.text: Wherefore, whensoever he may be made into an image, inasmuch as he exists in the six powers, he will exist (there) substantially, potentially, quantitively, (and) completely.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 7:10
verses.text: (And he will be a power) one and the same with the unbegotten and indefinite power, and not labouring under any greater deficiency than that unbegotten and unalterable (and) indefinite power.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 7:11
verses.text: If, however, he may continue only potentially in the six powers, and has not been formed into an image, he vanishes, he says, and is destroyed in such a way as the grammatical or geometrical capacity in man's soul.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 7:12
verses.text: For when the capacity takes unto itself an art, a light of existent things is produced; but when (the capacity) does not take unto itself (an art), unskilfulness and ignorance are the results; and just as when (the power) was non-existent, it perishes along with the expiring man.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 8

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 8:1
verses.text: Further Progression of This Threefold Emanation; Co-Existence with the Double Triad of a Seventh Existence.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 8:2
verses.text: And of those six powers, and of the seventh which co-exists with them, the first pair, Mind and Intelligence, he calls Heaven and Earth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 8:3
verses.text: And that one of these, being of male sex, beholds from above and takes care of his partner, but that the earth receives below the rational fruits, akin to the earth, which are borne down from the heaven.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 8:4
verses.text: On this account, he says, the Logos, frequently looking towards the things that are being generated from Mind and Intelligence, that is, from Heaven and Earth, exclaims, "Hear, O heaven, and give ear, O earth, because the Lord has spoken.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 8:5
verses.text: I have brought forth children, and exalted them; and these have rejected me".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 8:6
verses.text: Now, he who utters these words, he says, is the seventh power—he who stood, stands, and will stand; for he himself is cause of those beauteous objects of creation which Moses commended, and said that they were very good.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 8:7
verses.text: But Voice and Name (the second of the three pairs) are Sun and Moon; and Ratiocination and Reflection (the third of the three pairs) are Air and Water.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 8:8
verses.text: And in all these is intermingled and blended, as I have declared, the great, the indefinite, the (self-) existing power.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 9

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 9:1
verses.text: Simon's Interpretation of the Mosaic Hexaëmeron; His Allegorical Representation of Paradise.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 9:2
verses.text: When, therefore, Moses has spoken of "the six days in which God made heaven and earth, and rested on the seventh from all His works," Simon, in a manner already specified, giving (these and other passages of Scripture) a different application (from the one intended by the holy writers), deifies himself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 9:3
verses.text: When, therefore, (the followers of Simon) affirm that there are three days begotten before sun and moon, they speak enigmatically of Mind and Intelligence, that is, Heaven and Earth, and of the seventh power, (I mean) the indefinite one.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 9:4
verses.text: For these three powers are produced antecedent to all the rest.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 9:5
verses.text: But when they say, "He begot me prior to all the Ages," such statements, he says, are alleged to hold good concerning the seventh power.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 9:6
verses.text: Now this seventh power, which was a power existing in the indefinite power, which was produced prior to all the Ages, this is, he says, the seventh power, respecting which Moses utters the following words: "And the Spirit of God was wafted over the water;" that is, says (the Simonian), the Spirit which contains all things in itself, and is an image of the indefinite power about which Simon speaks,—"an image from an incorruptible form, that alone reduces all things into order".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 9:7
verses.text: For this power that is wafted over the water, being begotten, he says, from an incorruptible form alone, reduces all things into order.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 9:8
verses.text: When, therefore, according to these (heretics), there ensued some such arrangement, and (one) similar (to it) of the world, the Deity, he says, proceeded to form man, taking clay from the earth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 9:9
verses.text: And He formed him not uncompounded, but twofold, according to (His own) image and likeness.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 9:10
verses.text: Now the image is the Spirit that is wafted over the water; and whosoever is not fashioned into a figure of this, will perish with the world, inasmuch as he continues only potentially, and does exist actually.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 9:11
verses.text: This, he says, is what has been spoken, "that we should not be condemned with the world".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 9:12
verses.text: If one, however, be made into the figure of (the Spirit), and be generated from an indivisible point, as it has been written in the Announcement, (such a one, albeit) small, will become great.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 9:13
verses.text: But what is great will continue unto infinite and unalterable duration, as being that which no longer is subject to the conditions of a generated entity.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 9:14
verses.text: How then, he says, and in what manner, does God form man? In Paradise; for so it seems to him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 9:15
verses.text: Grant Paradise, he says, to be the womb; and that this is a true (assumption) the Scripture will teach, when it utters the words, "I am He who forms thee in thy mother's womb".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 9:16
verses.text: For this also he wishes to have been written so.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 9:17
verses.text: Moses, he says, resorting to allegory, has declared Paradise to be the womb, if we ought to rely on his statement.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 9:18
verses.text: If, however, God forms man in his mother's womb—that is, in Paradise—as I have affirmed, let Paradise be the womb, and Edem the after-birth, "a river flowing forth from Edem, for the purpose of irrigating Paradise," (meaning by this) the navel.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 9:19
verses.text: This navel, he says, is separated into four principles; for on either side of the navel are situated two arteries, channels of spirit, and two veins, channels of blood.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 9:20
verses.text: But when, he says, the umbilical vessels proceed forth from Edem, that is, the caul in which the foetus is enveloped grows into the (foetus) that is being formed in the vicinity of the epigastrium,—(now) all in common denominate this a navel,—these two veins through which the blood flows, and is conveyed from Edem, the after-birth, to what are styled the gates of the liver; (these veins, I say,) nourish the foetus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 9:21
verses.text: But the arteries which we have spoken of as being channels of spirit, embrace the bladder on both sides, around the pelvis, and connect it with the great artery, called the aorta, in the vicinity of the dorsal ridge.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 9:22
verses.text: And in this way the spirit, making its way through the ventricles to the heart, produces a movement of the foetus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 9:23
verses.text: For the infant that was formed in Paradise neither receives nourishment through the mouth, nor breathes through the nostrils: for as it lay in the midst of moisture, at its feet was death, if it attempted to breathe; for it would (thus) have been drawn away from moisture, and perished (accordingly).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 9:24
verses.text: But (one may go further than this); for the entire (foetus) is bound tightly round by a covering styled the caul, and is nourished by a navel, and it receives through the (aorta), in the vicinity of the dorsal ridge, as I have stated, the substance of the spirit.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 10

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 10:1
verses.text: Simon's Explanation of the First Two Books of Moses.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 10:2
verses.text: The river, therefore, he says, which proceeds out of Edem is divided into four principles, four channels—that is, into four senses, belonging to the creature that is being born, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 10:3
verses.text: , seeing, smelling, taste, and touch; for the child formed in Paradise has these senses only.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 10:4
verses.text: This, he says, is the law which Moses appointed; and in reference to this very law, each of his books has been written, as the inscriptions evince.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 10:5
verses.text: The first book is Genesis.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 10:6
verses.text: The inscription of the book is, he says, sufficient for a knowledge of the universe.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 10:7
verses.text: For this is (equivalent in meaning with) generation, (that is,) vision, into which one section of the river is divided.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 10:8
verses.text: For the world was seen by the power of vision.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 10:9
verses.text: Again, the inscription of the second book is Exodus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 10:10
verses.text: For what has been produced, passing through the Red Sea, must come into the wilderness,—now they say he calls the Red (Sea) blood,—and taste bitter water.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 10:11
verses.text: For bitter, he says, is the water which is (drunk) after (crossing) the Red Sea; which (water) is a path to be trodden, that leads (us) to a knowledge in (this) life of (our) toilsome and bitter lot.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 10:12
verses.text: Altered, however, by Moses—that is, by the Logos—that bitter (water) becomes sweet.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 10:13
verses.text: And that this is so we may hear in common from all who express themselves according to the (sentiments of the) poets:—  "Dark at the root, like milk, the flower,  Gods call it 'Moly,' and hard for mortal men  To dig, but power divine is boundless".

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 11

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 11:1
verses.text: Simon's Explanation of the Three Last Books of the Pentateuch.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 11:2
verses.text: What is spoken by the Gentiles is sufficient for a knowledge of the universe to those who have ears (capable) of hearing.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 11:3
verses.text: For whosoever, he says, has tasted this fruit, is not the only one that is changed by Circe into a beast; but also, employing the power of such a fruit, he forms anew and moulds afresh, and re-entices into that primary peculiar character of theirs, those that already have been altered into beasts.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 11:4
verses.text: But a faithful man, and beloved by that sorceress, is, he says, discovered through that milk-like and divine fruit.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 11:5
verses.text: In like manner, the third book is Leviticus, which is smelling, or respiration.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 11:6
verses.text: For the entire of that book is (an account) of sacrifices and offerings.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 11:7
verses.text: Where, however, there is a sacrifice, a certain savour of the fragrance arises from the sacrifice through the incense-offerings; and in regard of this fragrance (the sense of) smelling is a test.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 11:8
verses.text: Numbers, the fourth of the books, signifies taste, where the discourse is operative.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 11:9
verses.text: For, from the fact of its speaking all things, it is denominated by numerical arrangement.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 11:10
verses.text: But Deuteronomy, he says, is written in reference to the (sense of) touch possessed by the child that is being formed.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 11:11
verses.text: For as touch, by seizing the things that are seen by the other senses, sums them up and ratifies them, testing what is rough, or warm, or clammy, (or cold); so the fifth book of the law constitutes a summary of the four books preceding this.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 11:12
verses.text: All things, therefore, he says, when unbegotten, are in us potentially, not actually, as the grammatical or geometrical (art).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 11:13
verses.text: If, then, one receives proper instruction and teaching, and (where consequently) what is bitter will be altered into what is sweet,—that is, the spears into pruning-hooks, and the swords into plough-shares,—there will not be chaff and wood begotten for fire, but mature fruit, fully formed, as I said, equal and similar to the unbegotten and indefinite power.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 11:14
verses.text: If, however, a tree continues alone, not producing fruit fully formed, it is utterly destroyed.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 11:15
verses.text: For somewhere near, he says, is the axe (which is laid) at the roots of the tree.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 11:16
verses.text: Every tree, he says, which does not produce good fruit, is hewn down and cast into fire.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 12

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 12:1
verses.text: Fire a Primal Principle, According to Simon.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 12:2
verses.text: According to Simon, therefore, there exists that which is blessed and incorruptible in a latent condition in every one—(that is,) potentially, not actually; and that this is He who stood, stands, and is to stand.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 12:3
verses.text: He has stood above in unbegotten power.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 12:4
verses.text: He stands below, when in the stream of waters He was begotten in a likeness.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 12:5
verses.text: He is to stand above, beside the blessed indefinite power, if He be fashioned into an image.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 12:6
verses.text: For, he says, there are three who have stood; and except there were three aeons who have stood, the unbegotten one is not adorned.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 12:7
verses.text: (Now the unbegotten one) is, according to them, wafted over the water, and is re-made, according to the similitude (of an eternal nature), a perfect celestial (being), in no (quality of) intelligence formed inferior to the unbegotten power: that is what they say—I and you, one; you, before me; I, that which is after you.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 12:8
verses.text: This, he says, is one power divided above (and) below, generating itself, making itself grow, seeking itself, finding itself, being mother of itself, father of itself, sister of itself, spouse of itself, daughter of itself, son of itself, mother, father, a unit, being a root of the entire circle of existence.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 12:9
verses.text: And that, he says, the originating principle of the generation of things begotten is from fire, he discerns after some such method as the following.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 12:10
verses.text: Of all things, (i-e:) of whatsoever there is a generation, the beginning of the desire of the generation is from fire.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 12:11
verses.text: Wherefore the desire after mutable generation is denominated "to be inflamed".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 12:12
verses.text: For when the fire is one, it admits of two conversions.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 12:13
verses.text: For, he says, blood in the man being both warm and yellow, is converted as a figured flame into seed; but in the woman this same blood is converted into milk.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 12:14
verses.text: And the conversion of the male becomes generation, but the conversion of the female nourishment for the foetus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 12:15
verses.text: This, he says, is "the flaming sword, which turned to guard the way of the tree of life".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 12:16
verses.text: For the blood is converted into seed and milk, and this power becomes mother and father—father of those things that are in process of generation, and the augmentation of those things that are being nourished; (and this power is) without further want, (and) self-sufficient.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 12:17
verses.text: And, he says, the tree of life is guarded, as we have stated, by the brandished flaming sword.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 12:18
verses.text: And it is the seventh power, that which (is produced) from itself, (and) which contains all (powers, and) which reposes in the six powers.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 12:19
verses.text: For if the flaming sword be not brandished, that good tree will be destroyed, and perish.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 12:20
verses.text: If, however, these be converted into seed and milk, the principle that resides in these potentially, and is in possession of a proper position, in which is evolved a principle of souls, (such a principle,) beginning, as it were, from a very small spark, will be altogether magnified, and will increase and become a power indefinite (and) unalterable, (equal and similar) to an unalterable age, which no longer passes into the indefinite age.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 13

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 13:1
verses.text: His Doctrine of Emanation Further Expanded.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 13:2
verses.text: Therefore, according to this reasoning, Simon became confessedly a god to his silly followers, as that Libyan, namely, Apsethus—begotten, no doubt, and subject to passion, when he may exist potentially, but devoid of propensions.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 13:3
verses.text: (And this too, though born from one having propensions, and uncreated though born) from one that is begotten, when He may be fashioned into a figure, and, becoming perfect, may come forth from two of the primary powers, that is, Heaven and Earth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 13:4
verses.text: For Simon expressly speaks of this in the "Revelation" after this manner: "To you, then, I address the things which I speak, and (to you) I write what I write.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 13:5
verses.text: The writing is this: there are two offshoots from all the aeons, having neither beginning nor end, from one root.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 13:6
verses.text: And this is a power, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 13:7
verses.text: , Sige, (who is) invisible (and) incomprehensible.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 13:8
verses.text: And one of these (offshoots) appears from above, which constitutes a great power, (the creative) Mind of the universe, which manages all things, (and is) a male.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 13:9
verses.text: The other (offshoot), however, is from below, (and constitutes) a great Intelligence, and is a female which produces all things.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 13:10
verses.text: From whence, ranged in pairs opposite each other, they undergo conjugal union, and manifest an intermediate interval, namely, an incomprehensible air, which has neither beginning nor end.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 13:11
verses.text: But in this is a father who sustains all things, and nourishes things that have beginning and end.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 13:12
verses.text: This is he who stood, stands, and will stand, being an hermaphrodite power according to the pre-existent indefinite power, which has neither beginning nor end.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 13:13
verses.text: Now this (power) exists in isolation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 13:14
verses.text: For Intelligence, (that subsists) in unity, proceeded forth from this (power), (and) became two.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 13:15
verses.text: And that (father) was one, for having in himself this (power) he was isolated, and, however, He was not primal though pre-existent; but being rendered manifest to himself from himself, he passed into a state of duality.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 13:16
verses.text: But neither was he denominated father before this (power) would style him father.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 13:17
verses.text: As, therefore, he himself, bringing forward himself by means of himself, manifested unto himself his own peculiar intelligence, so also the intelligence, when it was manifested, did not exercise the function of creation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 13:18
verses.text: But beholding him, she concealed the Father within herself, that is, the power; and it is an hermaphrodite power, and an intelligence.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 13:19
verses.text: And hence it is that they are ranged in pairs, one opposite the other; for power is in no wise different from intelligence, inasmuch as they are one.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 13:20
verses.text: For from those things that are above is discovered power; and from those below, intelligence.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 13:21
verses.text: So it is, therefore, that likewise what is manifested from these, being unity, is discovered (to be) duality, an hermaphrodite having the female in itself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 13:22
verses.text: This, (therefore,) is Mind (subsisting) in Intelligence; and these are separable one from the other, (though both taken together) are one, (and) are discovered in a state of duality".

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 14

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 14:1
verses.text: Simon Interprets His System by the Mythological Representation of Helen of Troy; Gives an Account of Himself in Connection with the Trojan Heroine; Immorality of His Followers; Simon's View of Christ; The Simonists' Apology for Their Vice.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 14:2
verses.text: Simon then, after inventing these (tenets), not only by evil devices interpreted the writings of Moses in whatever way he wished, but even the (works) of the poets.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 14:3
verses.text: For also he fastens an allegorical meaning on (the story of) the wooden horse and Helen with the torch, and on very many other (accounts), which he transfers to what relates to himself and to Intelligence, and (thus) furnishes a fictitious explanation of them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 14:4
verses.text: He said, however, that this (Helen) was the lost sheep.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 14:5
verses.text: And she, always abiding among women, confounded the powers in the world by reason of her surpassing beauty.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 14:6
verses.text: Whence, likewise, the Trojan war arose on her account.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 14:7
verses.text: For in the Helen born at that time resided this Intelligence; and thus, when all the powers were for claiming her (for themselves), sedition and war arose, during which (this chief power) was manifested to nations.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 14:8
verses.text: And from this circumstance, without doubt, we may believe that Stesichorus, who had through (some) verses reviled her, was deprived of the use of his eyes; and that, again, when he repented and composed recantations, in which he sung (Helen's) praises, he recovered the power of vision.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 14:9
verses.text: But the angels and the powers below—who, he says, created the world—caused the transference from one body to another of (Helen's soul); and subsequently she stood on the roof of a house in Tyre, a city of Phoenicia, and on going down thither (Simon professed to have) found her.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 14:10
verses.text: For he stated that, principally for the purpose of searching after this (woman), he had arrived (in Tyre), in order that he might rescue her from bondage.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 14:11
verses.text: And after having thus redeemed her, he was in the habit of conducting her about with himself, alleging that this (girl) was the lost sheep, and affirming himself to be the Power above all things.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 14:12
verses.text: But the filthy fellow, becoming enamoured of this miserable woman called Helen, purchased her (as his slave), and enjoyed her person.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 14:13
verses.text: He, (however,) was likewise moved with shame towards his disciples, and concocted this figment.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 14:14
verses.text: But, again, those who become followers of this impostor—I mean Simon the sorcerer—indulge in similar practices, and irrationally allege the necessity of promiscuous intercourse.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 14:15
verses.text: They express themselves in the manner following: "All earth is earth, and there is no difference where any one sows, provided he does sow".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 14:16
verses.text: But even they congratulate themselves on account of this indiscriminate intercourse, asserting that this is perfect love, and employing the expressions, "holy of holies," and "sanctify one another".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 14:17
verses.text: For (they would have us believe) that they are not overcome by the supposed vice, for that they have been redeemed.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 14:18
verses.text: "And (Jesus), by having redeemed Helen in this way," (Simon says,) "has afforded salvation to men through his own peculiar intelligence.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 14:19
verses.text: For inasmuch as the angels, by reason of their lust for pre-eminence, improperly managed the world, (Jesus Christ) being transformed, and being assimilated to the rulers and powers and angels, came for the restoration (of things).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 14:20
verses.text: And so (it was that Jesus) appeared as man, when in reality he was not a man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 14:21
verses.text: And (so it was) that likewise he suffered—though not actually undergoing suffering, but appearing to the Jews to do so—in Judea as 'Son,' and in Samaria as 'Father,' and among the rest of the Gentiles as 'Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 14:22
verses.text: '" And (Simon alleges) that Jesus tolerated being styled by whichever name (of the three just mentioned) men might wish to call him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 14:23
verses.text: "And that the prophets, deriving their inspiration from the world-making angels, uttered predictions (concerning him)".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 14:24
verses.text: Wherefore, (Simon said,) that towards these (prophets) those felt no concern up to the present, who believe on Simon and Helen, and that they do whatsoever they please, as persons free; for they allege that they are saved by grace.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 14:25
verses.text: For that there is no reason for punishment, even though one shall act wickedly; for such a one is not wicked by nature, but by enactment.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 14:26
verses.text: "For the angels who created the world made," he says, "whatever enactments they pleased," thinking by such (legislative) words to enslave those who listened to them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 14:27
verses.text: But, again, they speak of a dissolution of the world, for the redemption of his own particular adherents.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 15

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 15:1
verses.text: Simon's Disciples Adopt the Mysteries; Simon Meets St.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 15:2
verses.text: Peter at Rome; Account of Simon's Closing Years.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 15:3
verses.text: The disciples, then, of this (Magus), celebrate magical rites, and resort to incantations.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 15:4
verses.text: And (they profess to) transmit both love-spells and charms, and the demons said to be senders of dreams, for the purpose of distracting whomsoever they please.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 15:5
verses.text: But they also employ those denominated Paredroi.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 15:6
verses.text: "And they have an image of Simon (fashioned) into the figure of Jupiter, and (an image) of Helen in the form of Minerva; and they pay adoration to these".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 15:7
verses.text: But they call the one Lord and the other Lady.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 15:8
verses.text: And if any one amongst them, on seeing the images of either Simon or Helen, would call them by name, he is cast off, as being ignorant of the mysteries.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 15:9
verses.text: This Simon, deceiving many in Samaria by his sorceries, was reproved by the Apostles, and was laid under a curse, as it has been written in the Acts.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 15:10
verses.text: But he afterwards abjured the faith, and attempted these (aforesaid practices).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 15:11
verses.text: And journeying as far as Rome, he fell in with the Apostles; and to him, deceiving many by his sorceries, Peter offered repeated opposition.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 15:12
verses.text: This man, ultimately repairing to…(and) sitting under a plane tree, continued to give instruction (in his doctrines).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 15:13
verses.text: And in truth at last, when conviction was imminent, in case he delayed longer, he stated that, if he were buried alive, he would rise the third day.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 15:14
verses.text: And accordingly, having ordered a trench to be dug by his disciples, he directed himself to be interred there.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 15:15
verses.text: They, then, executed the injunction given; whereas he remained (in that grave) until this day, for he was not the Christ.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 15:16
verses.text: This constitutes the legendary system advanced by Simon, and from this Valentinus derived a starting-point (for his own doctrine.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 15:17
verses.text: This doctrine, in point of fact, was the same with the Simonian, though Valentinus) denominated it under different titles: for "Nous," and "Aletheia," and "Logos," and "Zoe," and "Anthropos," and "Ecclesia," and aeons of Valentinus, are confessedly the six roots of Simon, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 15:18
verses.text: , "Mind" and "Intelligence," "Voice" and "Name," "Ratiocination" and "Reflection".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 15:19
verses.text: But since it seems to us that we have sufficiently explained Simon's tissue of legends, let us see what also Valentinus asserts.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 16

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 16:1
verses.text: Heresy of Valentinus; Derived from Plato and Pythagoras.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 16:2
verses.text: The heresy of Valentinus is certainly, then, connected with the Pythagorean and Platonic theory.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 16:3
verses.text: For Plato, in the Timaeus, altogether derives his impressions from Pythagoras, and therefore Timaeus himself is his Pythagorean stranger.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 16:4
verses.text: Wherefore, it appears expedient that we should commence by reminding (the reader) of a few points of the Pythagorean and Platonic theory, and that (then we should proceed) to declare the opinions of Valentinus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 16:5
verses.text: For even although in the books previously finished by us with so much pains, are contained the opinions advanced by both Pythagoras and Plato, yet at all events I shall not be acting unreasonably, in now also calling to the recollection of the reader, by means of an epitome, the principal heads of the favourite tenets of these (speculators).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 16:6
verses.text: And this (recapitulation) will facilitate our knowledge of the doctrines of Valentinus, by means of a nearer comparison, and by similarity of composition (of the two systems).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 16:7
verses.text: For (Pythagoras and Plato) derived these tenets originally from the Egyptians, and introduced their novel opinions among the Greeks.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 16:8
verses.text: But (Valentinus took his opinions) from these, because, although he has suppressed the truth regarding his obligations to (the Greek philosophers), and in this way has endeavoured to construct a doctrine, (as it were,) peculiarly his own, yet, in point of fact, he has altered the doctrines of those (thinkers) in names only, and numbers, and has adopted a peculiar terminology (of his own).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 16:9
verses.text: Valentinus has formed his definitions by measures, in order that he may establish an Hellenic heresy, diversified no doubt, but unstable, and not connected with Christ.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 17

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 17:1
verses.text: Origin of the Greek Philosophy.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 17:2
verses.text: The origin, then, from which Plato derived his theory in the Timaeus, is (the) wisdom of the Egyptians.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 17:3
verses.text: For from this source, by some ancient and prophetical tradition, Solon taught his entire system concerning the generation and destruction of the world, as Plato says, to the Greeks, who were (in knowledge) young children, and were acquainted with no theological doctrine of greater antiquity.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 17:4
verses.text: In order, therefore, that we may trace accurately the arguments by which Valentinus established his tenets, I shall now explain what are the principles of the philosophy of Pythagoras of Samos,—a philosophy (coupled) with that Silence so celebrated by the Greeks.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 17:5
verses.text: And next in this manner (I shall elucidate) those (opinions) which Valentinus derives from Pythagoras and Plato, but refers with all solemnity of speech to Christ, and before Christ to the Father of the universe, and to Silence conjoined with the Father.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 18

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 18:1
verses.text: Pythagoras' System of Numbers.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 18:2
verses.text: Pythagoras, then, declared the originating principle of the universe to be the unbegotten monad, and the generated duad, and the rest of the numbers.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 18:3
verses.text: And he says that the monad is the father of the duad, and the duad the mother of all things that are being begotten—the begotten one (being mother) of the things that are begotten.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 18:4
verses.text: And Zaratas, the pupil of Pythagoras, was in the habit of denominating unity a father, and duality a mother.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 18:5
verses.text: For the duad has been generated from the monad, according to Pythagoras; and the monad is male and primary, but the duad female (and secondary).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 18:6
verses.text: And from the duad, again, as Pythagoras states, (are generated) the triad and the succeeding numbers up to ten.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 18:7
verses.text: For Pythagoras is aware that this is the only perfect number—I mean the decade—for that eleven and twelve are an addition and repetition of the decade; not, however, that what is added constitutes the generation of another number.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 18:8
verses.text: And all solid bodies he generates from incorporeal (essences).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 18:9
verses.text: For he asserts that an element and principle of both corporeal and incorporeal entities is the point which is indivisible.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 18:10
verses.text: And from a point, he says, is generated a line, and from a line a surface; and a surface flowing out into a height becomes, he says, a solid body.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 18:11
verses.text: Whence also the Pythagoreans have a certain object of adjuration, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 18:12
verses.text: , the concord of the four elements.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 18:13
verses.text: And they swear in these words:—  "By him who to our head quaternion gives,  A font that has the roots of everlasting nature".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 18:14
verses.text: Now the quaternion is the originating principle of natural and solid bodies, as the monad of intelligible ones.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 18:15
verses.text: And that likewise the quaternion generates, he says, the perfect number, as in the case of intelligibles (the monad) does the decade, they teach thus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 18:16
verses.text: If any, beginning to number, says one, and adds two, then in like manner three, these (together) will be six, and to these (add) moreover four, the entire (sum), in like manner, will be ten.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 18:17
verses.text: For one, two, three, four, become ten, the perfect number.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 18:18
verses.text: Thus, he says, the quaternion in every respect imitated the intelligible monad, which was able to generate a perfect number.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 19

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 19:1
verses.text: Pythagoras' Duality of Substances; His "Categories".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 19:2
verses.text: There are, then, according to Pythagoras, two worlds: one intelligible, which has the monad for an originating principle; and the other sensible.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 19:3
verses.text: But of this (latter) is the quaternion having the iota, the one tittle, a perfect number.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 19:4
verses.text: And there likewise is, according to the Pythagoreans, the i, the one tittle, which is chief and most dominant, and enables us to apprehend the substance of those intelligible entities which are capable of being understood through the medium of intellect and of sense.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 19:5
verses.text: (And in this substance inhere) the nine incorporeal accidents which cannot exist without substance, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 19:6
verses.text: , "quality," and "quantity," and "relation," and "where," and "when," and "position," and "possession," and "action," and "passion".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 19:7
verses.text: These, then, are the nine accidents (inhering in) substance, and when reckoned with these (substances), contains the perfect number, the i.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 19:8
verses.text: Wherefore, the universe being divided, as we said, into the intelligible and sensible world, we have also reason from the intelligible (world), in order that by reason we may behold the substance of things that are cognised by intellect, and are incorporeal and divine.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 19:9
verses.text: But we have, he says, five senses—smelling, seeing, hearing, taste, and touch.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 19:10
verses.text: Now, by these we arrive at a knowledge of things that are discerned by sense; and so, he says, the sensible is divided from the intelligible world.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 19:11
verses.text: And that we have for each of these an instrument for attaining knowledge, we perceive from the following consideration.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 19:12
verses.text: Nothing, he says, of intelligibles can be known to us from sense.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 19:13
verses.text: For he says neither eye has seen, nor ear heard, nor any whatsoever of the other senses known that (which is cognised by mind).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 19:14
verses.text: Neither, again, by reason is it possible to arrive at a knowledge of any of the things discernible by sense.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 19:15
verses.text: But one must see that a thing is white, and taste that it is sweet, and know by hearing that it is musical or out of tune.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 19:16
verses.text: And whether any odour is fragrant or disagreeable, is the function of smell, not of reason.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 19:17
verses.text: It is the same with objects of touch; for anything rough, or soft, or warm, or cold, it is not possible to know by hearing, but (far from it), for touch is the judge of such (sensations).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 19:18
verses.text: Things being thus constituted, the arrangement of things that have been made and are being made is observed to happen in conformity with numerical (combinations).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 19:19
verses.text: For in the same manner as, commencing from monad, by an addition of monads or triads, and a collection of the succeeding numbers, we make some one very large complex whole of number; (and) then, again, from an amassed number thus formed by addition, we accomplish, by means of a certain subtraction and re-calculation, a solution of the totality of the aggregate numbers; so likewise he asserts that the world, bound by a certain arithmetical and musical chain, was, by its tension and relaxation, and by addition and subtraction, always and for ever preserved incorrupt.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 20

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 20:1
verses.text: Pythagoras' Cosmogony; Similar to that of Empedocles.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 20:2
verses.text: The Pythagoreans therefore declare their opinion concerning the continuance of the world in some such manner as this:—  "For heretofore it was and will be; never, I ween,  Of both of these will void the age eternal be".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 20:3
verses.text: "Of these;" but what are they? Discord and Love.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 20:4
verses.text: Now, in their system, Love forms the world incorruptible (and) eternal, as they suppose.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 20:5
verses.text: For substance and the world are one.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 20:6
verses.text: Discord, however, separates and puts asunder, and evinces numerous attempts by subdividing to form the world.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 20:7
verses.text: It is just as if one severs into small parts, and divides arithmetically, the myriad into thousands, and hundreds, and tens; and drachmae into oboli and small farthings.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 20:8
verses.text: In this manner, he says, Discord severs the substance of the world into animals, plants, metals and things similar to these.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 20:9
verses.text: And the fabricator of the generation of all things produced is, according to them, Discord; whereas Love, on the other hand, manages and provides for the universe in such a manner that it enjoys permanence.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 20:10
verses.text: And conducting together into unity the divided and scattered parts of the universe, and leading them forth from their (separate) mode of existence, (Love) unites and adds to the universe, in order that it may enjoy permanence; and it thus constitutes one system.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 20:11
verses.text: They will not therefore cease,—neither Discord dividing the world, nor Love attaching to the world the divided parts.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 20:12
verses.text: Of some such description as this, so it appears, is the distribution of the world according to Pythagoras.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 20:13
verses.text: But Pythagoras says that the stars are fragments from the sun, and that the souls of animals are conveyed from the stars; and that these are mortal when they are in the body, just as if buried, as it were, in a tomb: whereas that they rise (out of this world) and become immortal, when we are separated from our bodies.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 20:14
verses.text: Whence Plato, being asked by some one, "What is philosophy?" replied, "It is a separation of soul from body".

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 21

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 21:1
verses.text: Other Opinions of Pythagoras.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 21:2
verses.text: Pythagoras, then, became a student of these doctrines likewise, in which he speaks both by enigmas and some such expressions as these: "When you depart from your own (tabernacle), return not; if, however, (you act) not (thus), the Furies, auxiliaries to justice, will overtake you,"—denominating the body one's own (tabernacle), and its passions the Furies.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 21:3
verses.text: When, therefore, he says, you depart, that is, when you go forth from the body, do not earnestly crave for this; but if you are eagerly desirous (for departure), the passions will once more confine you within the body.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 21:4
verses.text: For these suppose that there is a transition of souls from one body to another, as also Empedocles, adopting the principles of Pythagoras, affirms.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 21:5
verses.text: For, says he, souls that are lovers of pleasure, as Plato states, if, when they are in the condition of suffering incidental to man, they do not evolve theories of philosophy, must pass through all animals and plants (back) again into a human body.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 21:6
verses.text: And when (the soul) may form a system of speculation thrice in the same body, (he maintains) that it ascends up to the nature of some kindred star.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 21:7
verses.text: If, however, (the soul) does not philosophize, (it must pass) through the same (succession of changes once more).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 21:8
verses.text: He affirms, then, that the soul sometimes may become even mortal, if it is overcome by the Furies, that is, the passions (of the body); and immortal, if it succeeds in escaping the Furies, which are the passions.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 22

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 22:1
verses.text: The "Sayings" Of Pythagoras.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 22:2
verses.text: But since also we have chosen to mention the sayings darkly expressed by Pythagoras to his disciples by means of symbols, it seems likewise expedient to remind (the reader) of the rest (of his doctrines.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 22:3
verses.text: And we touch on this subject) on account also of the heresiarchs, who attempt by some method of this description to converse by means of symbols; and these are not their own, but they have, (in propounding them,) taken advantage of expressions employed by the Pythagoreans.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 22:4
verses.text: Pythagoras then instructs his disciples, addressing them as follows: "Bind up the sack that carries the bedding".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 22:5
verses.text: (Now,) inasmuch as they who intend going upon a journey tie their clothes into a wallet, to be ready for the road; so, (in like manner,) he wishes his disciples to be prepared, since every moment death is likely to come upon them by surprise.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 22:6
verses.text: (In this way Pythagoras sought to effect) that (his followers) should labour under no deficiency in the qualifications required in his pupils.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 22:7
verses.text: Wherefore of necessity he was in the habit, with the dawn of day, of instructing the Pythagoreans to encourage one another to bind up the sack that carries the bedding, that is, to be ready for death.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 22:8
verses.text: "Do not stir fire with a sword;" (meaning,) do not, by addressing him, quarrel with an enraged man; for a person in a passion is like fire, whereas the sword is the uttered expression.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 22:9
verses.text: "Do not trample on a besom;" (meaning,) despise not a small matter.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 22:10
verses.text: "Plant not a palm tree in a house;" (meaning,) foment not discord in a family, for the palm tree is a symbol of battle and slaughter.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 22:11
verses.text: "Eat not from a stool;" (meaning,) do not undertake an ignoble art, in order that you may not be a slave to the body, which is corruptible, but make a livelihood from literature.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 22:12
verses.text: For it lies within your reach both to nourish the body, and make the soul better.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 22:13
verses.text: "Don't take a bite out of an uncut loaf;" (meaning,) diminish not thy possessions, but live on the profit (of them), and guard thy substance as an entire loaf.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 22:14
verses.text: "Feed not on beans; (meaning,) accept not the government of a city, for with beans they at that time were accustomed to ballot for their magistrates.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 23

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 23:1
verses.text: Pythagoras' Astronomic System.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 23:2
verses.text: These, then, and such like assertions, the Pythagoreans put forward; and the heretics, imitating these, are supposed by some to utter important truths.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 23:3
verses.text: The Pythagorean system, however, lays down that the Creator of all alleged existences is the Great Geometrician and Calculator—a sun; and that this one has been fixed in the whole world, just as in the bodies a soul, according to the statement of Plato.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 23:4
verses.text: For the sun (being of the nature of) fire, resembles the soul, but the earth (resembles the) body.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 23:5
verses.text: And, separated from fire, there would be nothing visible, nor would there be any object of touch without something solid; but not any solid body exists without earth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 23:6
verses.text: Whence the Deity, locating air in the midst, fashioned the body of the universe out of fire and earth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 23:7
verses.text: And the Sun, he says, calculates and geometrically measures the world in some such manner as the following: The world is a unity cognizable by sense; and concerning this (world) we now make these assertions.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 23:8
verses.text: But one who is an adept in the science of numbers, and a geometrician, has divided it into twelve parts.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 23:9
verses.text: And the names of these parts are as follow: Aries, Taurus, Gemini, Cancer, Leo, Virgo, Libra, Scorpio, Sagittarius, Capricorn, Aquarius, Pisces.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 23:10
verses.text: Again, he divides each of the twelve parts into thirty parts, and these are days of the month.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 23:11
verses.text: Again, he divides each part of the thirty parts into sixty small divisions, and (each) of these small (divisions) he subdivides into minute portions, and (these again) into portions still more minute.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 23:12
verses.text: And always doing this, and not intermitting, but collecting from these divided portions (an aggregate), and constituting it a year; and again resolving and dividing the compound, (the sun) completely finishes the great and everlasting world.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 24

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 24:1
verses.text: Valentinus Convicted of Plagiarisms from the Platonic and Pythagoric Philosophy; The Valentinian Theory of Emanation by Duads.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 24:2
verses.text: Of some such nature, as I who have accurately examined their systems (have attempted) to state compendiously, is the opinion of Pythagoras and Plato.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 24:3
verses.text: And from this (system), not from the Gospels, Valentinus, as we have proved, has collected the (materials of) heresy—I mean his own (heresy)—and may (therefore) justly be reckoned a Pythagorean and Platonist, not a Christian.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 24:4
verses.text: Valentinus, therefore, and Heracleon, and Ptolemaeus, and the entire school of these (heretics), as disciples of Pythagoras and Plato, (and) following these guides, have laid down as a fundamental principle of their doctrine the arithmetical system.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 24:5
verses.text: For, likewise, according to these (Valentinians), the originating cause of the universe is a Monad, unbegotten, imperishable, incomprehensible, inconceivable, productive, and a cause of the generation of all existent things.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 24:6
verses.text: And the aforesaid Monad is styled by them Father.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 24:7
verses.text: There is, however, discoverable among them some considerable diversity of opinion.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 24:8
verses.text: For some of them, in order that the Pythagorean doctrine of Valentinus may be altogether free from admixture (with other tenets), suppose that the Father is unfeminine, and unwedded, and solitary.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 24:9
verses.text: But others, imagining it to be impossible that from a male only there could proceed a generation at all of any of those things that have been made to exist, necessarily reckon along with the Father of the universe, in order that he may be a father, Sige as a spouse.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 24:10
verses.text: But as to Sige, whether at any time she is united in marriage (to the Father) or not, this is a point which we leave them to wrangle about among themselves.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 24:11
verses.text: We at present, keeping to the Pythagorean principle, which is one, and unwedded, unfeminine, (and) deficient in nothing, shall proceed to give an account of their doctrines, as they themselves inculcate them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 24:12
verses.text: There is, says (Valentinus), not anything at all begotten, but the Father is alone unbegotten, not subject to the condition of place, not (subject to the condition of) time, having no counsellor, (and) not being any other substance that could be realized according to the ordinary methods of perception.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 24:13
verses.text: (The Father,) however, was solitary, subsisting, as they say, in a state of quietude, and Himself reposing in isolation within Himself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 24:14
verses.text: When, however, He became productive, it seemed to Him expedient at one time to generate and lead forth the most beautiful and perfect (of those germs of existence) which He possessed within Himself, for (the Father) was not fond of solitariness.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 24:15
verses.text: For, says he, He was all love, but love is not love except there may be some object of affection.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 24:16
verses.text: The Father Himself, then, as He was solitary, projected and produced Nous and Aletheia, that is, a duad which became mistress, and origin, and mother of all the aeons computed by them (as existing) within the Pleroma.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 24:17
verses.text: Nous and Aletheia being projected from the Father, one capable of continuing generation, deriving existence from a productive being, (Nous) himself likewise, in imitation of the Father, projected Logos and Zoe; and Logos and Zoe project Anthropos and Ecclesia.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 24:18
verses.text: But Nous and Aletheia, when they beheld that their own offspring had been born productive, returned thanks to the Father of the universe, and offer unto Him a perfect number, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 24:19
verses.text: , ten aeons.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 24:20
verses.text: For, he says, Nous and Aletheia could not offer unto the Father a more perfect (one) than this number.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 24:21
verses.text: For the Father, who is perfect, ought to be celebrated by a perfect number, and ten is a perfect number, because this is first of those (numbers) that are formed by plurality, (and therefore) perfect.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 24:22
verses.text: The Father, however, being more perfect, because being alone unbegotten, by means of the one primary conjugal union of Nous and Aletheia, found means of projecting all the roots of existent things.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 25

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 25:1
verses.text: The Tenet of the Duad Made the Foundation of Valentinus' System of the Emanation of aeons.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 25:2
verses.text: Logos himself also, and Zoe, then saw that Nous and Aletheia had celebrated the Father of the universe by a perfect number; and Logos himself likewise with Zoe wished to magnify their own father and mother, Nous and Aletheia.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 25:3
verses.text: Since, however, Nous and Aletheia were begotten, and did not possess paternal (and) perfect uncreatedness, Logos and Zoe do not glorify Nous their father with a perfect number, but far from it, with an imperfect one.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 25:4
verses.text: For Logos and Zoe offer twelve aeons unto Nous and Aletheia.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 25:5
verses.text: For, according to Valentinus, these—namely, Nous and Aletheia, Logos and Zoe, Anthropos and Ecclesia—have been the primary roots of the aeons.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 25:6
verses.text: But there are ten aeons proceeding from Nous and Aletheia, and twelve from Logos and Zoe—twenty and eight in all.
