verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 25:7
verses.text: And to these (ten) they give these following denominations: Bythus and Mixis, Ageratus and Henosis, Autophyes and Hedone, Acinetus and Syncrasis, Monogenes and Macaria.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 25:8
verses.text: These are ten aeons whom some say (have been projected) by Nous and Aletheia, but some by Logos and Zoe.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 25:9
verses.text: Others, however, affirm that the twelve (aeons have been projected) by Anthropos and Ecclesia, while others by Logos and Zoe.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 25:10
verses.text: And upon these they bestow these following names: Paracletus and Pistis, Patricus and Elpis, Metricus and Agape, aeinous and Synesis, Ecclesiasticus and Macariotes, Theletus and Sophia.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 25:11
verses.text: But of the twelve, the twelfth and youngest of all the twenty-eight aeons, being a female, and called Sophia, observed the multitude and power of the begetting aeons, and hurried back into the depth of the Father.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 25:12
verses.text: And she perceived that all the rest of the aeons, as being begotten, generate by conjugal intercourse.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 25:13
verses.text: The Father, on the other hand, alone, without copulation, has produced (an offspring).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 25:14
verses.text: She wished to emulate the Father, and to produce (offspring) of herself without a marital partner, that she might achieve a work in no wise inferior to (that of) the Father.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 25:15
verses.text: (Sophia, however,) was ignorant that the Unbegotten One, being an originating principle of the universe, as well as root and depth and abyss, alone possesses the power of self-generation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 25:16
verses.text: But Sophia, being begotten, and born after many more (aeons), is not able to acquire possession of the power inherent in the Unbegotten One.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 25:17
verses.text: For in the Unbegotten One, he says, all things exist simultaneously, but in the begotten (aeons) the female is projective of substance, and the male is formative of the substance which is projected by the female.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 25:18
verses.text: Sophia, therefore, prepared to project that only which she was capable (of projecting), viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 25:19
verses.text: , a formless and undigested substance.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 25:20
verses.text: And this, he says, is what Moses asserts: "The earth was invisible, and unfashioned".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 25:21
verses.text: This (substance) is, he says, the good (and) the heavenly Jerusalem, into which God has promised to conduct the children of Israel, saying, "I will bring you into a land flowing with milk and honey".

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 26

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 26:1
verses.text: Valentinus' Explanation of the Existence of Christ and the Spirit.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 26:2
verses.text: Ignorance, therefore, having arisen within the Pleroma in consequence of Sophia, and shapelessness in consequence of the offspring of Sophia, confusion arose in the Pleroma.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 26:3
verses.text: (For all) the aeons that were begotten (became overwhelmed with apprehension, imagining) that in like manner formless and incomplete progenies of the aeons should be generated; and that some destruction, at no distant period, should at length seize upon the aeons.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 26:4
verses.text: All the aeons, then, betook themselves to supplication of the Father, that he would tranquillize the sorrowing Sophia; for she continued weeping and bewailing on account of the abortion produced by her,—for so they term it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 26:5
verses.text: The Father, then, compassionating the tears of Sophia, and accepting the supplication of the aeons, orders a further projection.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 26:6
verses.text: For he did not, (Valentinus) says, himself project, but Nous and Aletheia (projected) Christ and the Holy Spirit for the restoration of Form, and the destruction of the abortion, and (for) the consolation and cessation of the groans of Sophia.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 26:7
verses.text: And thirty aeons came into existence along with Christ and the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 26:8
verses.text: Some of these (Valentinians) wish that this should be a triacontad of aeons, whereas others desire that Sige should exist along with the Father, and that the aeons should be reckoned along with them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 26:9
verses.text: Christ, therefore, being additionally projected, and the Holy Spirit, by Nous and Aletheia, immediately this abortion of Sophia, (which was) shapeless, (and) born of herself only, and generated without conjugal intercourse, separates from the entire of the aeons, lest the perfect aeons, beholding this (abortion), should be disturbed by reason of its shapelessness.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 26:10
verses.text: In order, then, that the shapelessness of the abortion might not at all manifest itself to the perfect aeons, the Father also again projects additionally one aeon, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 26:11
verses.text: , Staurus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 26:12
verses.text: And he being begotten great, as from a mighty and perfect father, and being projected for the guardianship and defence of the aeons, becomes a limit of the Pleroma, having within itself all the thirty aeons together, for these are they that had been projected.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 26:13
verses.text: Now this (aeon) is styled Horos, because he separates from the Pleroma the Hysterema that is outside.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 26:14
verses.text: And (he is called) Metocheus, because he shares also in the Hysterema.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 26:15
verses.text: And (he is denominated) Staurus, because he is fixed inflexibly and inexorably, so that nothing of the Hysterema can come near the aeons who are within the Pleroma.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 26:16
verses.text: Outside, then, Horos, (or) Metocheus, (or) Staurus, is the Ogdoad, as it is called, according to them, and is that Sophia which is outside the Pleroma, which (Sophia) Christ, who was additionally projected by Nous and Aletheia, formed and made a perfect aeon so that in no respect she should be inferior in power to any of the aeons within the Pleroma.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 26:17
verses.text: Since, however, Sophia was formed outside, and it was not possible and equitable that Christ and the Holy Spirit, who were projected from Nous and Aletheia, should remain outside the Pleroma, Christ hurried away, and the Holy Spirit, from her who had had shape imparted to her, unto Nous and Aletheia within the Limit, in order that with the rest of the aeons they might glorify the Father.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 27

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 27:1
verses.text: Valentinus' Explanation of the Existence of Jesus; Power of Jesus Over Humanity.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 27:2
verses.text: After, then, there ensued some one (treaty of) peace and harmony between all the aeons within the Pleroma, it appeared expedient to them not only by a conjugal union to have magnified the Son, but also that by an offering of ripe fruits they should glorify the Father.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 27:3
verses.text: Then all the thirty aeons consented to project one aeon, joint fruit of the Pleroma, that he might be (an earnest) of their union, and unanimity, and peace.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 27:4
verses.text: And he alone was projected by all the aeons in honour of the Father.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 27:5
verses.text: This (one) is styled among them "Joint Fruit of the Pleroma".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 27:6
verses.text: These (matters), then, took place within the Pleroma in this way.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 27:7
verses.text: And the "Joint Fruit of the Pleroma" was projected, (that is,) Jesus,—for this is his name,—the great High Priest.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 27:8
verses.text: Sophia, however, who was outside the Pleroma in search of Christ, who had given her form, and of the Holy Spirit, became involved in great terror that she would perish, if he should separate from her, who had given her form and consistency.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 27:9
verses.text: And she was seized with grief, and fell into a state of considerable perplexity, (while) reflecting who was he who had given her form, what the Holy Spirit was, whither he had departed, who it was that had hindered them from being present, who it was that had been envious of that glorious and blessed spectacle.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 27:10
verses.text: While involved in sufferings such as these, she turns herself to prayer and supplication of him who had deserted her.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 27:11
verses.text: During the utterance of her entreaties, Christ, who is within the Pleroma, had mercy upon (her), and all the rest of the aeons (were similarly affected); and they send forth beyond the Pleroma "the Joint Fruit of the Pleroma" as a spouse for Sophia, who was outside, and as a rectifier of those sufferings which she underwent in searching after Christ.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 27:12
verses.text: "The Fruit," then, arriving outside the Pleroma, and discovering (Sophia) in the midst of those four primary passions, both fear and sorrow, and perplexity and entreaty, he rectified her affections.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 27:13
verses.text: While, however, correcting them, he observed that it would not be proper to destroy these, inasmuch as they are (in their nature) eternal, and peculiar to Sophia; and yet that neither was it seemly that Sophia should exist in the midst of such passions, in fear and sorrow, supplication (and) perplexity.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 27:14
verses.text: He therefore, as an aeon so great, and (as) offspring of the entire Pleroma, caused the passions to depart from her, and he made these substantially-existent essences.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 27:15
verses.text: He altered fear into animal desire, and (made) grief material, and (rendered) perplexity (the passion) of demons.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 27:16
verses.text: But conversion, and entreaty, and supplication, he constituted as a path to repentance and power over the animal essence, which is denominated right.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 27:17
verses.text: The Creator (acted) from fear; (and) that is what, he says, Scripture affirms: "The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 27:18
verses.text: For this is the beginning of the affections of Sophia, for she was seized with fear, next with grief, then with perplexity, and so she sought refuge in entreaty and supplication.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 27:19
verses.text: And the animal essence is, he says, of a fiery nature, and is also termed by them the super-celestial Topos, and Hebdomad, and "Ancient of Days".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 27:20
verses.text: And whatever other such statements they advance respecting this (aeon), these they allege to hold good of the animalish (one), whom they assert to be creator of the world.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 27:21
verses.text: Now he is of the appearance of fire.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 27:22
verses.text: Moses also, he says, expresses himself thus: "The Lord thy God is a burning and consuming fire".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 27:23
verses.text: For he, likewise, wishes (to think) that it has been so written.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 27:24
verses.text: There is, however, he says, a twofold power of the fire; for fire is all-consuming, (and) cannot be quenched.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 27:25
verses.text: According, therefore, to this division, there exists, subject to death, a certain soul which is a sort of mediator, for it is a Hebdomad and Cessation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 27:26
verses.text: For underneath the Ogdoad, where Sophia is, but above Matter, which is the Creator, a day has been formed, and the "Joint Fruit of the Pleroma".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 27:27
verses.text: If the soul has been fashioned in the image of those above, that is, the Ogdoad, it became immortal and repaired to the Ogdoad, which is, he says, heavenly Jerusalem.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 27:28
verses.text: If, however, it has been fashioned in the image of Matter, that is, the corporeal passions, the soul is of a perishable nature, and is (accordingly) destroyed.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 28

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 28:1
verses.text: The Valentinian Origin of the Creation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 28:2
verses.text: As, therefore, the primary and greatest power of the animal essence came into existence, an image (of the only begotten Son); so also the devil, who is the ruler of this world, constitutes the power of the material essence, as Beelzebub is of the essence of demons which emanates from anxiety.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 28:3
verses.text: (In consequence of this,) Sophia from above exerted her energy from the Ogdoad to the Hebdomad.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 28:4
verses.text: For the Demiurge, they say, knows nothing at all, but is, according to them, devoid of understanding, and silly, and is not conscious of what he is doing or working at.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 28:5
verses.text: But in him, while thus in a state of ignorance that even he is producing, Sophia wrought all sorts of energy, and infused vigour (into him).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 28:6
verses.text: And (although Sophia) was really the operating cause, he himself imagines that he evolves the creation of the world out of himself: whence he commenced, saying, "I am God, and beside me there is no other".

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 29

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 29:1
verses.text: The Other Valentinian Emanations in Conformity with the Pythagorean System of Numbers.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 29:2
verses.text: The quaternion, then, advocated by Valentinus, is "a source of the everlasting nature having roots;" and Sophia (is the power) from whom the animal and material creation has derived its present condition.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 29:3
verses.text: But Sophia is called "Spirit," and the Demiurge "Soul," and the Devil "the ruler of this world," and Beelzebub "the (ruler) of demons".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 29:4
verses.text: These are the statements which they put forward.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 29:5
verses.text: But further, in addition to these, rendering, as I have previously mentioned, their entire system of doctrine (akin to the) arithmetical (art), (they determine) that the thirty aeons within the Pleroma have again, in addition to these, projected other aeons, according to the (numerical) proportion (adopted by the Pythagoreans), in order that the Pleroma might be formed into an aggregate, according to a perfect number.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 29:6
verses.text: For how the Pythagoreans divided (the celestial sphere) into twelve and thirty and sixty parts, and how they have minute parts of diminutive portions, has been made evident.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 29:7
verses.text: In this manner these (followers of Valentinus) subdivide the parts within the Pleroma.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 29:8
verses.text: Now likewise the parts in the Ogdoad have been subdivided, and there has been projected Sophia, which is, according to them, mother of all living creatures, and the "Joint Fruit of the Pleroma," (who is) the Logos, (and other aeons,) who are celestial angels that have their citizenship in Jerusalem which is above, which is in heaven.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 29:9
verses.text: For this Jerusalem is Sophia, she (that is) outside (the Pleroma), and her spouse is the "Joint Fruit of the Pleroma".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 29:10
verses.text: And the Demiurge projected souls; for this (Sophia) is the essence of souls.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 29:11
verses.text: This (Demiurge), according to them, is Abraham, and these (souls) the children of Abraham.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 29:12
verses.text: From the material and devilish essence the Demiurge fashioned bodies for the souls.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 29:13
verses.text: This is what has been declared: "And God formed man, taking clay from the earth, and breathed upon his face the breath of life, and man was made into a living soul".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 29:14
verses.text: This, according to them, is the inner man, the natural (man), residing in the material body: Now a material (man) is perishable, incomplete, (and) formed out of the devilish essence.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 29:15
verses.text: And this is the material man, as it were, according to them an inn, or domicile, at one time of soul only, at another time of soul and demons, at another time of soul and Logoi.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 29:16
verses.text: And these are the Logoi that have been dispersed from above, from the "Joint Fruit of the Pleroma" and (from) Sophia, into this world.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 29:17
verses.text: And they dwell in an earthly body, with a soul, when demons do not take up their abode with that soul.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 29:18
verses.text: This, he says, is what has been written in Scripture: "On this account I bend my knees to the God and Father and Lord of our Lord Jesus Christ, that God would grant you to have Christ dwelling in the inner man,"—that is, the natural (man), not the corporeal (one),—"that you may be able to understand what is the depth," which is the Father of the universe, "and what is the breadth," which is Staurus, the limit of the Pleroma, "or what is the length," that is, the Pleroma of the aeons.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 29:19
verses.text: Wherefore, he says, "the natural man receiveth not the things of the Spirit of God, for they are foolishness unto him;" but folly, he says, is the power of the Demiurge, for he was foolish and devoid of understanding, and imagined himself to be fabricating the world.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 29:20
verses.text: He was, however, ignorant that Sophia, the Mother, the Ogdoad, was really the cause of all the operations performed by him who had no consciousness in reference to the creation of the world.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 30

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 30:1
verses.text: Valentinus' Explanation of the Birth of Jesus; Twofold Doctrine on the Nature of Jesus' Body; Opinion of the Italians, that Is, Heracleon and Ptolemaeus; Opinion of the Orientals, that Is, Axionicus and Bardesanes.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 30:2
verses.text: All the prophets, therefore, and the law, spoke by means of the Demiurge,—a silly god, he says, (and themselves) fools, who knew nothing.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 30:3
verses.text: On account of this, he says, the Saviour observes: "All that came before me are thieves and robbers".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 30:4
verses.text: And the apostle (uses these words): "The mystery which was not made known to former generations".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 30:5
verses.text: For none of the prophets, he says, said anything concerning the things of which we speak; for (a prophet) could not but be ignorant of all (these) things, inasmuch as they certainly had been uttered by the Demiurge only.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 30:6
verses.text: When, therefore, the creation received completion, and when after (this) there ought to have been the revelation of the sons of God—that is, of the Demiurge, which up to this had been concealed, and in which obscurity the natural man was hid, and had a veil upon the heart;—when (it was time), then, that the veil should be taken away, and that these mysteries should be seen, Jesus was born of Mary the virgin, according to the declaration (in Scripture), "The Holy Ghost will come upon thee"—Sophia is the Spirit—"and the power of the Highest will overshadow thee"—the Highest is the Demiurge,—"wherefore that which shall be born of thee shall be called holy".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 30:7
verses.text: For he has been generated not from the highest alone, as those created in (the likeness of) Adam have been created from the highest alone—that is, (from) Sophia and the Demiurge.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 30:8
verses.text: Jesus, however, the new man, (has been generated) from the Holy Spirit—that is, Sophia and the Demiurge—in order that the Demiurge may complete the conformation and constitution of his body, and that the Holy Spirit may supply his essence, and that a celestial Logos may proceed from the Ogdoad being born of Mary.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 30:9
verses.text: Concerning this (Logos) they have a great question amongst them—an occasion both of divisions and dissension.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 30:10
verses.text: And hence the doctrine of these has become divided: and one doctrine, according to them, is termed Oriental, and the other Italian.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 30:11
verses.text: They from Italy, of whom is Heracleon and Ptolemaeus, say that the body of Jesus was (an) animal (one).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 30:12
verses.text: And on account of this, (they maintain) that at his baptism the Holy Spirit as a dove came down—that is, the Logos of the mother above, (I mean Sophia)—and became (a voice) to the animal (man), and raised him from the dead.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 30:13
verses.text: This, he says, is what has been declared: "He who raised Christ from the dead will also quicken your mortal and natural bodies".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 30:14
verses.text: For loam has come under a curse; "for," says he, "dust thou art, and unto dust shalt thou return".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 30:15
verses.text: The Orientals, on the other hand, of whom is Axionicus and Bardesianes, assert that the body of the Saviour was spiritual; for there came upon Mary the Holy Spirit—that is, Sophia and the power of the highest.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 30:16
verses.text: This is the creative art, (and was vouchsafed) in order that what was given to Mary by the Spirit might be fashioned.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 31

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 31:1
verses.text: Further Doctrines of Valentinus Respecting the aeons; Reasons for the Incarnation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 31:2
verses.text: Let, then, those (heretics) pursue these inquiries among themselves, (and let others do so likewise,) if it should prove agreeable to anybody else to investigate (such points.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 31:3
verses.text: Valentinus) subjoins, however, the following statement: That the trespasses appertaining to the aeons within (the Pleroma) had been corrected; and likewise had been rectified the trespasses appertaining to the Ogdoad, (that is,) Sophia, outside (the Pleroma); and also (the trespasses) appertaining to the Hebdomad (had been rectified).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 31:4
verses.text: For the Demiurge had been taught by Sophia that He is not Himself God alone, as He imagined, and that except Himself there is not another (Deity).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 31:5
verses.text: But when taught by Sophia, He was made to recognise the superior (Deity).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 31:6
verses.text: For He was instructed by her, and initiated and indoctrinated into the great mystery of the Father and of the aeons, and divulged this to none.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 31:7
verses.text: This is, as he says, what (God) declares to Moses: "I am the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob; and my name I have not announced to them;" that is, I have not declared the mystery, nor explained who is God, but I have preserved the mystery which I have heard from Sophia in secrecy with myself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 31:8
verses.text: When, then, the trespasses of those above had been rectified, it was necessary, according to the same consequence, that the (transgressions) here likewise should obtain rectification.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 31:9
verses.text: On this account Jesus the Saviour was born of Mary that he might rectify (the trespasses committed) here; as the Christ who, having been projected additionally from above by Nous and Aletheia, had corrected the passions of Sophia—that is, the abortion (who was) outside (the Pleroma).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 31:10
verses.text: And, again, the Saviour who was born of Mary came to rectify the passions of the soul.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 31:11
verses.text: There are therefore, according to these (heretics), three Christs: (the first the) one additionally projected by Nous and Aletheia, along with the Holy Spirit; and (the second) the "Joint Fruit of the Pleroma," spouse of Sophia, who was outside (the Pleroma).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 31:12
verses.text: And she herself is likewise styled Holy Spirit, but one inferior to the first (projection).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 31:13
verses.text: And the third (Christ is) He who was born of Mary for the restoration of this world of ours.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 32

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 32:1
verses.text: Valentinus Convicted of Plagiarisms from Plato.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 32:2
verses.text: I think that the heresy of Valentinus which is of Pythagorean (origin), has been sufficiently, indeed more than sufficiently, delineated.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 32:3
verses.text: It therefore seems also expedient, that having explained his opinions, we should desist from (further) refutation (of his system).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 32:4
verses.text: Plato, then, in expounding mysteries concerning the universe, writes to Dionysius expressing himself after some such manner as this: "I must speak to you by riddles, in order that if the letter may meet with any accident in its leaves by either sea or land, he who reads (what falls into his hands) may not understand it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 32:5
verses.text: For so it is.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 32:6
verses.text: All things are about the King of all, and on his account are all things, and he is cause of all the glorious (objects of creation).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 32:7
verses.text: The second is about the second, and the third about the third.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 32:8
verses.text: But pertaining to the King there is none of those things of which I have spoken.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 32:9
verses.text: But after this the soul earnestly desires to learn what sort these are, looking upon those things that are akin to itself, and not one of these is (in itself) sufficient.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 32:10
verses.text: This is, O son of Dionysius and Doris, the question (of yours) which is a cause of all evil things.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 32:11
verses.text: Nay, but rather the solicitude concerning this is innate in the soul; and if one does not remove this, he will never really attain truth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 32:12
verses.text: But what is astonishing in this matter, listen.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 32:13
verses.text: For there are men who have heard these things—(men) furnished with capacities for learning, and furnished with capacities of memory, and persons who altogether in every way are endued with an aptitude for investigation with a view to inference.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 32:14
verses.text: (These are) at present aged speculators.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 32:15
verses.text: And they assert that opinions which at one time were credible are now incredible, and that things once incredible are now the contrary.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 32:16
verses.text: While, therefore, turning the eye of examination towards these (inquiries), exercise caution, lest at any time you should have reason to repent in regard of those things should they happen in a manner unbecoming to your dignity.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 32:17
verses.text: On this account I have written nothing concerning these (points); nor is there any treatise of Plato's (upon them), nor ever shall there be.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 32:18
verses.text: The observations, however, now made are those of Socrates, conspicuous for virtue even while he was a young man".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 32:19
verses.text: Valentinus, falling in with these (remarks), has made a fundamental principle in his system "the King of all," whom Plato mentioned, and whom this heretic styles Pater, and Bythos, and Proarche over the rest of the aeons.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 32:20
verses.text: And when Plato uses the words, "what is second about things that are second," Valentinus supposes to be second all the aeons that are within the limit (of the Pleroma, as well as) the limit (itself).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 32:21
verses.text: And when Plato uses the words, "what is third about what is third," he has (constituted as third) the entire of the arrangement (existing) outside the limit and the Pleroma.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 32:22
verses.text: And Valentinus has elucidated this (arrangement) very succinctly, in a psalm commencing from below, not as Plato does, from above, expressing himself thus: "I behold all things suspended in air by spirit, and I perceive all things wafted by spirit; the flesh (I see) suspended from soul, but the soul shining out from air, and air depending from aether, and fruits produced from Bythus, and the foetus borne from the womb".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 32:23
verses.text: Thus (Valentinus) formed his opinion on such (points).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 32:24
verses.text: Flesh, according to these (heretics), is matter which is suspended from the soul of the Demiurge.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 32:25
verses.text: And soul shines out from air; that is, the Demiurge emerges from the spirit, (which is) outside the Pleroma.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 32:26
verses.text: But air springs forth from aether; that is, Sophia, which is outside (the Pleroma, is projected from the Pleroma) which is within the limit, and (from) the entire Pleroma (generally).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 32:27
verses.text: And from Bythus fruits are produced; (that is,) the entire projection of the aeons is made from the Father.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 32:28
verses.text: The opinions, then, advanced by Valentinus have been sufficiently declared.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 32:29
verses.text: It remains for us to explain the tenets of those who have emanated from his school, though each adherent (of Valentinus) entertains different opinions.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 33

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 33:1
verses.text: Secundus' System of aeons; Epiphanes; Ptolemaeus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 33:2
verses.text: A certain (heretic) Secundus, born about the same time with Ptolemaeus, expresses himself thus: (he says) that there is a right tetrad and a left tetrad,—namely, light and darkness.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 33:3
verses.text: And he affirms that the power which withdrew and laboured under deficiency, was not produced from the thirty aeons, but from the fruits of these.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 33:4
verses.text: Some other (heretic), however—Epiphanes, a teacher among them—expresses himself thus: "The earliest originating principle was inconceivable, ineffable, and unnameable;" and he calls this Monotes.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 33:5
verses.text: And (he maintains) that there co-exists with this (principle) a power which he denominates Henotes.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 33:6
verses.text: This Henotes and this Monotes, not by projection (from themselves), sent forth a principle (that should preside) over all intelligibles; (and this was) both unbegotten and invisible, and he styles it a Monad.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 33:7
verses.text: "With this power co-exists a power of the same essence, which very (power) I call Unity.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 33:8
verses.text: These four powers sent forth the remainder of the projections of the aeons".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 33:9
verses.text: But others, again, denominate the chief and originating Ogdoad, (which is) fourth (and) invisible, by the following names: first, Proarche; next, Anennoetus; third, Arrhetus; and fourth, Aoratus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 33:10
verses.text: And that from the first, Proarche, was projected by a first and fifth place, Arche; and from Anennoetus, by a second and sixth place, Acataleptus; and from Arrhetus, by a third and seventh place, Anonomastus; and from Aoratus, Agennetus, a complement of the first Ogdoad.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 33:11
verses.text: They wish that these powers should exist before Bythus and Sige.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 33:12
verses.text: Concerning, however, Bythus himself, there are many different opinions.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 33:13
verses.text: Some affirm him to be unwedded, neither male nor female; but others (maintain) that Sige, who is a female, is present with him, and that this constitutes the first conjugal union.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 33:14
verses.text: But the followers of Ptolemaeus assert that (Bythus) has two spouses, which they call likewise dispositions, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 33:15
verses.text: , Ennoia and Thelesis (conception and volition).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 33:16
verses.text: For first the notion was conceived of projecting anything; next followed, as they say, the will to do so.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 33:17
verses.text: Wherefore also these two dispositions and powers—namely, Ennoia and Thelesis—being, as it were, mingled one with the other, there ensued a projection of Monogenes and Aletheia by means of a conjugal union.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 33:18
verses.text: And the consequence was, that visible types and images of those two dispositions of the Father came forth from the invisible (aeons), viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 33:19
verses.text: , from Thelema, Nous, and from Ennoia, Aletheia.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 33:20
verses.text: And on this account the image of the subsequently generated Thelema is (that of a) male; but (the image) of the unbegotten Ennoia is (that of a) female, since volition is, as it were, a power of conception.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 33:21
verses.text: For conception always cherished the idea of a projection, yet was not of itself at least able to project itself, but cherished the idea (of doing so).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 33:22
verses.text: When, however, the power of volition (would be present), then it projects the idea which had been conceived.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 34

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 34:1
verses.text: System of Marcus; A Mere Impostor; His Wicked Devices Upon the Eucharistic Cup.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 34:2
verses.text: A certain other teacher among them, Marcus, an adept in sorcery, carrying on operations partly by sleight of hand and partly by demons, deceived many from time to time.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 34:3
verses.text: This (heretic) alleged that there resided in him the mightiest power from invisible and unnameable places.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 34:4
verses.text: And very often, taking the Cup, as if offering up the Eucharistic prayer, and prolonging to a greater length than usual the word of invocation, he would cause the appearance of a purple, and sometimes of a red mixture, so that his dupes imagined that a certain Grace descended and communicated to the potion a blood-red potency.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 34:5
verses.text: The knave, however, at that time succeeded in escaping detection from many; but now, being convicted (of the imposture), he will be forced to desist from it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 34:6
verses.text: For, infusing secretly into the mixture some drug that possessed the power of imparting such a colour (as that alluded to above), uttering for a considerable time nonsensical expressions, he was in the habit of waiting, (in expectation) that the (drug), obtaining a supply of moisture, might be dissolved, and, being intermingled with the potion, might impart its colour to it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 34:7
verses.text: The drugs, however, that possess the quality of furnishing this effect we have previously mentioned in the book on magicians.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 34:8
verses.text: And here we have taken occasion to explain how they make dupes of many, and thoroughly ruin them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 34:9
verses.text: And if it should prove agreeable to them to apply their attention with greater accuracy to the statement made by us, they will become aware of the deceit of Marcus.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 35

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 35:1
verses.text: Further Acts of Jugglery on the Part of Marcus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 35:2
verses.text: And this (Marcus), infusing (the aforesaid) mixture into a smaller cup, was in the habit of delivering it to a woman to offer up the Eucharistic prayer, while he himself stood by, and held (in his hand) another empty (chalice) larger than that.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 35:3
verses.text: And after his female dupe had pronounced the sentence of Consecration, having received (the cup from her), he proceeded to infuse (its contents) into the larger (chalice), and, pouring them frequently from one cup to the other, was accustomed at the same time to utter the following invocation: "Grant that the inconceivable and ineffable Grace which existed prior to the universe, may fill thine inner man, and make to abound in thee the knowledge of this (grace), as She disseminates the seed of the mustard-tree upon the good soil".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 35:4
verses.text: And simultaneously pronouncing some such words as these, and astonishing both his female dupe and those that are present, he was regarded as one performing a miracle; while the larger was being filled from the smaller chalice, in such a way as that (the contents), being superabundant, flowed over.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 35:5
verses.text: And the contrivance of this (juggler) we have likewise explained in the aforesaid (fourth) book, where we have proved that very many drugs, when mingled in this way with liquid substances, are endued with the quality of yielding augmentation, more particularly when diluted in wine.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 35:6
verses.text: Now, when (one of these impostors) previously smears, in a clandestine manner, an empty cup with any one of these drugs, and shows it (to the spectators) as if it contained nothing, by infusing into it (the contents) from the other cup, and pouring them back again, the drug, as it is of a flatulent nature, is dissolved by being blended with the moist substance.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 35:7
verses.text: And the effect of this was, that a superabundance of the mixture ensued, and was so far augmented, that what was infused was put in motion, such being the nature of the drug.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 35:8
verses.text: And if one stow away (the chalice) when it has been filled, (what has been poured into it) will after no long time return to its natural dimensions, inasmuch as the potency of the drug becomes extinct by reason of the continuance of moisture.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 35:9
verses.text: Wherefore he was in the habit of hurriedly presenting the cup to those present, to drink; but they, horrified at the same time, and eager (to taste the contents of the cup), proceeded to drink (the mixture), as if it were something divine, and devised by the Deity.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 36

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 36:1
verses.text: The Heretical Practices of the Marcites in Regard of Baptism.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 36:2
verses.text: Such and other (tricks) this impostor attempted to perform.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 36:3
verses.text: And so it was that he was magnified by his dupes, and sometimes he was supposed to utter predictions.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 36:4
verses.text: But sometimes he tried to make others (prophesy), partly by demons carrying on these operations, and partly by practising sleight of hand, as we have previously stated.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 36:5
verses.text: Hoodwinking therefore multitudes, he led on (into enormities) many (dupes) of this description who had become his disciples, by teaching them that they were prone, no doubt, to sin, but beyond the reach of danger, from the fact of their belonging to the perfect power, and of their being participators in the inconceivable potency.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 36:6
verses.text: And subsequent to the (first) baptism, to these they promise another, which they call Redemption.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 36:7
verses.text: And by this (other baptism) they wickedly subvert those that remain with them in expectation of redemption, as if persons, after they had once been baptized, could again obtain remission.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 36:8
verses.text: Now, it is by means of such knavery as this that they seem to retain their hearers.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 36:9
verses.text: And when they consider that these have been tested, and are able to keep (secret the mysteries) committed unto them, they then admit them to this (baptism).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 36:10
verses.text: They, however, do not rest satisfied with this alone, but promise (their votaries) some other (boon) for the purpose of confirming them in hope, in order that they may be inseparable (adherents of their sect).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 36:11
verses.text: For they utter something in an inexpressible (tone of) voice, after having laid hands on him who is receiving the redemption.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 36:12
verses.text: And they allege that they could not easily declare (to another) what is thus spoken unless one were highly tested, or one were at the hour of death, (when) the bishop comes and whispers (it) into the (expiring one's) ear.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 36:13
verses.text: And this knavish device (is undertaken) for the purpose of securing the constant attendance upon the bishop of (Marcus') disciples, as individuals eagerly panting to learn what that may be which is spoken at the last, by (the knowledge of) which the learner will be advanced to the rank of those admitted into the higher mysteries.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 36:14
verses.text: And in regard of these I have maintained a silence for this reason, lest at any time one should suppose that I was guilty of disparaging these (heretics).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 36:15
verses.text: For this does not come within the scope of our present work, only so far as it may contribute to prove from what source (the heretics) have derived the standing-point from which they have taken occasion to introduce the opinions advanced by them.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 37

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 37:1
verses.text: Marcus' System Explained by Irenaeus; Marcus' Vision; The Vision of Valentinus Revealing to Him His System.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 37:2
verses.text: For also the blessed presbyter Irenaeus, having approached the subject of a refutation in a more unconstrained spirit, has explained such washings and redemptions, stating more in the way of a rough digest what are their practices.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 37:3
verses.text: (And it appears that some of the Marcosians,) on meeting with (Irenaeus' work), deny that they have so received (the secret word just alluded to), but they have learned that always they should deny.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 37:4
verses.text: Wherefore our anxiety has been more accurately to investigate, and to discover minutely what are the (instructions) which they deliver in the case of the first bath, styling it by some such name; and in the case of the second, which they denominate Redemption.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 37:5
verses.text: But not even has this secret of theirs escaped (our scrutiny).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 37:6
verses.text: For these opinions, however, we consent to pardon Valentinus and his school.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 37:7
verses.text: But Marcus, imitating his teacher, himself also feigns a vision, imagining that in this way he would be magnified.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 37:8
verses.text: For Valentinus likewise alleges that he had seen an infant child lately born; and questioning (this child), he proceeded to inquire who it might be.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 37:9
verses.text: And (the child) replied, saying that he himself is the Logos, and then subjoined a sort of tragic legend; and out of this (Valentinus) wishes the heresy attempted by him to consist.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 37:10
verses.text: Marcus, making a similar attempt with this (heretic), asserts that the Tetrad came to him in the form of a woman,—since the world could not bear, he says, the male (form) of this Tetrad, and that she revealed herself who she was, and explained to this (Marcus) alone the generation of the universe, which she never had revealed to any, either of gods or of men, expressing herself after this mode: When first the self-existent Father, He who is inconceivable and without substance, He who is neither male nor female, willed that His own ineffability should become realized in something spoken, and that His invisibility should become realized in form, He opened His mouth, and sent forth similar to Himself a Logos.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 37:11
verses.text: And this (Logos) stood by Him, and showed unto Him who he was, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 37:12
verses.text: , that he himself had been manifested as a (realization in) form of the Invisible One.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 37:13
verses.text: And the pronunciation of the name was of the following description.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 37:14
verses.text: He was accustomed to utter the first word of the name itself, which was Arche, and the syllable of this was (composed) of four letters.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 37:15
verses.text: Then he subjoined the second (syllable), and this was also (composed) of four letters.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 37:16
verses.text: Next he uttered the third (syllable), which was (composed) of ten letters; and he uttered the fourth (syllable), and this was (composed) of twelve letters.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 37:17
verses.text: Then ensued the pronunciation of the entire name, (composed) of thirty letters, but of four syllables.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 37:18
verses.text: And each of the elements had its own peculiar letters, and its own peculiar form, and its own peculiar pronunciation, as well as figures and images.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 37:19
verses.text: And not one of these was there that beholds the form of that (letter) of which this was an element.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 37:20
verses.text: And of course none of them could know the pronunciation of the (letter) next to this, but (only) as he himself pronounces it, (and that in such a way) as that, in pronouncing the whole (word), he supposed that he was uttering the entire (name).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 37:21
verses.text: For each of these (elements), being part of the entire (name), he denominates (according to) its own peculiar sound, as if the whole (of the word).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 37:22
verses.text: And he does not intermit sounding until he arrived at the last letter of the last element, and uttered it in a single articulation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 37:23
verses.text: Then he said, that the restoration of the entire ensued when all the (elements), coming down into the one letter, sounded one and the same pronunciation, and an image of the pronunciation he supposed to exist when we simultaneously utter the word Amen.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 37:24
verses.text: And that these sounds are those which gave form to the insubstantial and unbegotten aeon, and that those forms are what the Lord declared to be angels—the (forms) that uninterruptedly behold the face of the Father.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 38

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 38:1
verses.text: Marcus' System of Letters.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 38:2
verses.text: But the generic and expressed names of the elements he called aeons, and Logoi, and Roots, and Seeds, and Pleromas, and Fruits.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 38:3
verses.text: (And he maintains) that every one of these, and what was peculiar to each, is perceived as being contained in the name of "Ecclesia".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 38:4
verses.text: And the final letter of the last element sent forth its own peculiar articulation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 38:5
verses.text: And the sound of this (letter) came forth and produced, in accordance with images of the elements, its own peculiar elements.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 38:6
verses.text: And from these he says that things existing here were garnished, and the things antecedent to these were produced.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 38:7
verses.text: The letter itself certainly, of which the sound was concomitant with the sound below, he says, was received up by its own syllable into the complement of the entire (name); but that the sound, as if cast outside, remained below.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 38:8
verses.text: And that the element itself, from which the letter along with its own pronunciation descended below, he says, is (composed) of thirty letters, and that each one of the thirty letters contains in itself other letters, by means of which the title of the letter is named.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 38:9
verses.text: And again, that the other (letters) are named by different letters, and the rest by different (ones still).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 38:10
verses.text: So that by writing down the letters individually, the number would eventuate in infinity.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 38:11
verses.text: In this way one may more clearly understand what is spoken.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 38:12
verses.text: The element Delta, (he says,) has five letters in itself, (viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 38:13
verses.text: ), Delta, and Epsilon, and Lambda, and Tau, and Alpha; and these very letters are (written) by means of other letters.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 38:14
verses.text: If, therefore, the entire substance of the Delta eventuates in infinity, (and if) different letters invariably produce different letters, and succeed one another, by how much greater than that element is the more enormous sea of the letters? And if one letter is thus infinite, behold the entire name's depth of the letters out of which the patient industry, nay, rather (I should say,) the vain toil of Marcus wishes that the Progenitor (of things) should consist! Wherefore also (he maintains) that the Father, who knew that He was inseparable from Himself, gave (this depth) to the elements, which he likewise denominates aeons.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 38:15
verses.text: And he uttered aloud to each one of them its own peculiar pronunciation, from the fact that one could not pronounce the entire.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 39

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 39:1
verses.text: The Quaternion Exhibits "Truth".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 39:2
verses.text: And (Marcus alleged) that the Quaternion, after having explained these things, spoke as follows: "Now, I wish also to exhibit to you Truth herself, for I have brought her down from the mansions above, in order that you may behold her naked, and become acquainted with her beauty; nay, also that you may hear her speak, and may marvel at her wisdom.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 39:3
verses.text: Observe," says the Quaternion, "then, first, the head above, Alpha (and long) O; the neck, B and Psi; shoulders, along with hands, G and Chi; breasts, Delta and Phi; diaphragm, Eu; belly, Z and T; pudenda, Eta and S; thighs, Th and R; knees, Ip; calves, Ko; ankles, Lxsi; feet, M and N".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 39:4
verses.text: This is in the body of Truth, according to Marcus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 39:5
verses.text: This is the figure of the element; this the character of the letter.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 39:6
verses.text: And he styles this element Man, and affirms it to be the source of every word, and the originating principle of every sound, and the realization in speech of everything that is ineffable, and a mouth of taciturn silence.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 39:7
verses.text: And this is the body of (Truth) herself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 39:8
verses.text: But do you, raising aloft the conceiving power of the understanding, hear from the mouths of Truth (of) the Logos, who is Self-generator and Progenitor.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 40

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 40:1
verses.text: The Name of Christ Jesus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 40:2
verses.text: But, after uttering these words, (Marcus details) that Truth, gazing upon him, and opening her mouth, spoke the discourse (just-alluded to).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 40:3
verses.text: And (he tells us) that the discourse became a name, and that the name was that which we know and utter, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 40:4
verses.text: , Christ Jesus, and that as soon as she had named this (name) she remained silent.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 40:5
verses.text: While Marcus, however, was expecting that she was about to say more, the Quaternion, again advancing into the midst, speaks as follows: "Thou didst regard as contemptible this discourse which you have heard from the mouth of Truth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 40:6
verses.text: And yet this which you know and seem long since to possess is not the name; for you have merely the sound of it, but are ignorant of the power.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 40:7
verses.text: For Jesus is a remarkable name, having six letters, invoked by all belonging to the called (of Christ); whereas the other (name, that is, Christ,) consists of many parts, and is among the (five) aeons of the Pleroma.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 40:8
verses.text: (This name) is of another form and a different type, and is recognised by those existences who are connate with him, and whose magnitudes subsist with him continually.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 41

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 41:1
verses.text: Marcus' Mystic Interpretation of the Alphabet.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 41:2
verses.text: Know, (therefore,) that these letters which with you are (reckoned at) twenty-four, are emanations from the three powers, and are representative of those (powers) which embrace even the entire number of the elements.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 41:3
verses.text: For suppose that there are some letters that are mute—nine of them—of Pater and Aletheia, from the fact that these are mute—that is, ineffable and unutterable.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 41:4
verses.text: And (again, assume) that there are other (letters that are) semi-vowels—eight of them—of the Logos and of Zoe, from the fact that these are intermediate between consonants and vowels, and receive the emanation of the (letters) above them, but the reflux of those below them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 41:5
verses.text: And (likewise take for granted) that there are vowels—and these are seven—of Anthropos and Ecclesia, inasmuch as the voice of Anthropos proceeded forth, and imparted form to the (objects of the) universe.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 41:6
verses.text: For the sound of the voice produced figure, and invested them with it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 41:7
verses.text: From this it follows that there are Logos and Zoe, which have eight (semi-vowels); and Anthropos and Ecclesia, which have seven (vowels); and Pater and Aletheia, which have nine (mutes).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 41:8
verses.text: But from the fact that Logos wanted (one of being an ogdoad), he who is in the Father was removed (from his seat on God's right hand), and came down (to earth).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 41:9
verses.text: And he was sent forth (by the Father) to him from whom he was separated, for the rectification of actions that had been committed.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 41:10
verses.text: (And his descent took place) in order that the unifying process, which is inherent in Agathos, of the Pleromas might produce in all the single power that emanates from all.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 41:11
verses.text: And thus he who is of the seven (vowels) acquired the power of the eight (semi-vowels); and there were produced three topoi, corresponding with the (three) numbers (nine, seven, and eight),—(these topoi) being ogdoads.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 41:12
verses.text: And these three being added one to the other, exhibited the number of the twenty-four (letters).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 41:13
verses.text: And (he maintains), of course, that the three elements,—(which he himself affirms to be (allied) with the three powers by conjugal union, and which (by this state of duality) become six, and from which have emanated the twenty-four elements,—being rendered fourfold by the Quaternion's ineffable word, produce the same number (twenty-four) with these.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 41:14
verses.text: And these, he says, belong to Anonomastus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 41:15
verses.text: And (he asserts) that these are conveyed by the six powers into a similarity with Aoratus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 41:16
verses.text: And (he says) that there are six double letters of these elements, images of images, which, being reckoned along with the twenty-four letters, produce, by an analogical power, the number thirty.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 42

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 42:1
verses.text: His System Applied to Explain Our Lord's Life and Death.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 42:2
verses.text: And he says, as the result of this computation and that proportion, that in the similitude of an image He appeared who after the six days Himself ascended the mountain a fourth person, and became the sixth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 42:3
verses.text: And (he asserts) that He (likewise) descended and was detained by the Hebdomad, and thus became an illustrious Ogdoad.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 42:4
verses.text: And He contains in Himself of the elements the entire number which He manifested, as He came to His baptism.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 42:5
verses.text: (And the symbol of manifestation was) the descent of the dove, which is Omega and Alpha, and which by the number manifested (by these is).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 42:6
verses.text: And for this reason (he maintains) that Moses says that man was created on the sixth day.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 42:7
verses.text: And (he asserts) that the dispensation of suffering (took place) on the sixth day, which is the preparation; (and so it was) that on this (day) appeared the last man for the regeneration of the first man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 42:8
verses.text: And that the beginning and end of this dispensation is the sixth hour, at which He was nailed to the (accursed) tree.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 42:9
verses.text: For (he says) that perfect Nous, knowing the sixfold number to be possessed of the power of production and regeneration, manifested to the sons of light the regeneration that had been introduced into this number by that illustrious one who had appeared.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 42:10
verses.text: Whence also he says that the double letters involve the remarkable number.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 42:11
verses.text: For the illustrious number, being intermingled with the twenty-four elements, produced the name (consisting) of the thirty letters.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 43

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 43:1
verses.text: Letters, Symbols of the Heavens.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 43:2
verses.text: He has, however, employed the instrumentality of the aggregate of the seven numbers, in order that the result of the self-devised (counsel) might be manifested.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 43:3
verses.text: Understand, he says, for the present, that remarkable number to be Him who was formed by the illustrious one, and who was, as it were, divided, and remained outside.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 43:4
verses.text: And He, through both His Own power and wisdom, by means of the projection of Himself, imparted, in imitation of the seven powers, animation to this world, so as to make it consist of seven powers, and constituted (this world) the soul of the visible universe.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 43:5
verses.text: And therefore this one has resorted to such all operation as what was spontaneously undertaken by Himself; and these minister, inasmuch as they are imitations of things inimitable, unto the intelligence of the Mother.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 43:6
verses.text: And the first heaven sounds Alpha, and the one after that Epsilon, and the third Eta, and the fourth, even that in the midst of the seven (vowels, enunciates) the power of Iota, and the fifth of Omicron, and the sixth of Upsilon, and the seventh and fourth from the central one, Omega.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 43:7
verses.text: And all the powers, when they are connected together in one, emit a sound, and glorify that (Being) from whom they have been projected.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 43:8
verses.text: And the glory of that sound is transmitted upwards to the Progenitor.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 43:9
verses.text: And furthermore, he says that the sound of this ascription of glory being conveyed to the earth, became a creator and producer of terrestrial objects.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 43:10
verses.text: And (he maintains) that the proof of this (may be drawn) from the case of infants recently born, whose soul, simultaneously with exit from the womb utters similarly this sound of each one of the elements.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 43:11
verses.text: As, then, he says, the seven powers glorify the Logos, so also does the sorrowing soul in babes (magnify Him).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 43:12
verses.text: And on account of this, he says, David likewise has declared, "Out of the mouths of babes and sucklings Thou hast perfected praise".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 43:13
verses.text: And again, "The heavens declare the glory of God".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 43:14
verses.text: When, however, the soul is involved in hardships, it utters no other exclamation than the Omega, inasmuch as it is afflicted in order that the soul above, becoming aware of what is akin to herself (below), may send down one to help this (earthly soul).

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 44

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 44:1
verses.text: Respecting the Generation of the Twenty-Four Letters.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 44:2
verses.text: And so far for these points.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 44:3
verses.text: Respecting, however, the generation of the twenty-four elements, he expresses himself thus: that Henotes coexists with Monotes, and that from these issue two projections, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 44:4
verses.text: , Monas and Hen, and that these being added together become four, for twice two are four.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 44:5
verses.text: And again, the two and four (projections) being added together, manifested the number six; and these six made fourfold, produce the twenty-four forms.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 44:6
verses.text: And these are the names of the first tetrad, and they are understood as Holy of Holies, and cannot be expressed and they are recognised by the Son alone.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 44:7
verses.text: These the Father knows which they are.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 44:8
verses.text: Those names which with Him are pronounced in silence and with faith, are Arrhetus and Sige, Pater and Aletheia.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 44:9
verses.text: And of this tetrad the entire number is (that) of twenty-four letters.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 44:10
verses.text: For Arrhetus has seven elements, Sige five, and Pater five, and Aletheia seven.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 44:11
verses.text: And in like manner also (is it with) the second tetrad; (for) Logos and Zoe, Anthropos and Ecclesia, exhibited the same number of elements.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 44:12
verses.text: And (he says) that the expressed name—(that is, Jesus)—of the Saviour consists of six letters, but that His ineffable name, according to the number of the letters, one by one, consists of twenty-four elements, but Christ a Son of twelve.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 44:13
verses.text: And (he says) that the ineffable (name) in Christ consists of thirty letters, and this exists, according to the letters which are in Him, the elements being counted one by one.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 44:14
verses.text: For the (name) Christ consists of eight elements; for Chi consists of three, and Rho of two, and EI of two, and Iota, of four, Sigma of five, and Tau of three, and OU of two, and San of three.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 44:15
verses.text: Thus the ineffable name in Christ consists, they allege, of thirty letters.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 44:16
verses.text: And they assert that for this reason He utters the words, "I am Alpha and Omega," displaying the dove, which (symbolically) has this number, which is eight hundred and one.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 45

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 45:1
verses.text: Why Jesus is Called Alpha.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 45:2
verses.text: Now Jesus possesses this ineffable generation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 45:3
verses.text: For from the mother of the universe, I mean the first tetrad, proceeded forth, in the manner of a daughter, the second tetrad.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 45:4
verses.text: And it became an ogdoad, from which proceeded forth the decade; and thus was produced ten, and next eighteen.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 45:5
verses.text: The decade, therefore, coming in along with the ogdoad, and rendering it tenfold, produced the number eighty; and again making eighty tenfold, generated the number eight hundred.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 45:6
verses.text: And so it is that the entire number of letters that proceeded forth from ogdoad into decade is eight hundred and eighty-eight, which is Jesus; for the name Jesus, according to the number in letters, is eight hundred and eighty-eight.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 45:7
verses.text: Now likewise the Greek alphabet has eight monads and eight decades, and eight hecatontads; and these exhibit the calculated sum of eight hundred and eighty-eight, that is, Jesus, who consists of all numbers.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 45:8
verses.text: And that on this account He is called Alpha (and Omega), indicating His generation (to be) from all.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 46

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 46:1
verses.text: Marcus' Account of the Birth and Life of Our Lord.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 46:2
verses.text: But concerning the creation of this (Jesus), he expresses himself thus: That powers emanating from the second tetrad fashioned Jesus, who appeared on earth, and that the angel Gabriel filled the place of the Logos, and the Holy Spirit that of Zoe, and the "Power of the Highest" that of Anthropos, and the Virgin that of Ecclesia.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 46:3
verses.text: And so it was, in Marcus' system, that the man (who appeared) in accordance with the dispensation was born through Mary.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 46:4
verses.text: And when He came to the water, (he says) that He descended like a dove upon him who had ascended above and filled the twelfth number.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 46:5
verses.text: And in Him resides the seed of these, that is, such as are sown along with Him, and that descend with (Him), and ascend with (Him).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 46:6
verses.text: And that this power which descended upon Him, he says, is the seed of the Pleroma, which contains in itself both the Father and the Son, and the unnameable power of Sige, which is recognised through these and all the aeons.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 46:7
verses.text: And that this (seed) is the spirit which is in Him and spoke in Him through the mouth of the Son, the confession of Himself as Son of man, and of His being one who would manifest the Father; (and that) when this spirit came down upon Jesus, He was united with Him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 46:8
verses.text: The Saviour, who was of the dispensation, he says, destroyed death, whereas He made known (as) the Father Christ (Jesus).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 46:9
verses.text: He says that Jesus, therefore, is the name of the man of the dispensation, and that it has been set forth for the assimilation and formation of Anthropos, who was about to descend upon Him; and that when He had received Him unto Himself, He retained possession of Him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 46:10
verses.text: And (he says) that He was Anthropos, (that) He (was) Logos, (that) He (was) Pater, and Arrhetus, and Sige, and Aletheia, and Ecclesia, and Zoe.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 47

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 47:1
verses.text: The System of Marcus Shown to Be that of Pythagoras, by Quotations from the Writings of Marcus' Followers.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 47:2
verses.text: I trust, therefore, that as regards these doctrines it is obvious to all possessed of a sound mind, that (these tenets) are unauthoritative, and far removed from the knowledge that is in accordance with Religion, and are mere portions of astrological discovery, and the arithmetical art of the Pythagoreans.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 47:3
verses.text: And this assertion, ye who are desirous of learning shall ascertain (to be true, by a reference to the previous books, where,) amongst other opinions elucidated by us, we have explained these doctrines likewise.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 47:4
verses.text: In order, however, that we may prove it a more clear statement, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 47:5
verses.text: , that these (Marcosians) are disciples not of Christ but of Pythagoras, I shall proceed to explain those opinions that have been derived (by these heretics) from Pythagoras concerning the meteoric (phenomena) of the stars as far as it is possible (to do so) by an epitome.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies V 47:6
